reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked this game up late Alpha 0.56a and I got very addicted, very quickly. The game at the moment is riddled with bugs but for the first full two days of gameplay, it didn’t bother me whatsoever, each time I disconnected I found myself rushing to get back in to return my endless search for keys and then the doors for those keys.

One thing that I found that is a bit negative towards the game is the Phantom, I don’t consider it overpowered but I consider it is… how to put it. Not used correctly. The game is suppose, in my mind be a survival horror. In other words I find that the goal of the monster whatever type that may be, should be to try to scare the survivors in any possible way, from talking creepy in the microphone to chasing a survivor, and letting them get away. I’ve found the best matches I’ve had are with people who just installed the game, the environment is new, they don’t know the mechanics of it yet and pretty much anything give them a little jump. Nothing is more satisfying as the monster to hear them scream and run when you spawn behind them, and give them a little growl. I don’t think the majority of the community follows this ideal of the monster however.

I’ve noticed in most lobbies people let everything stay on random. But, sometimes you have someone select something, and nearly 99% of the time they choose the Phantom. Then exactly what I expect happens, the phantom rushes the spawning points kills all the survivors in cramped narrow hallways then proceeds to give remarks like. “Yes!” and “Owned!” in the lobby, like they actually accomplished anything more than simple spawn killing. The impact on the survivors is that they didn’t care, they didn’t get scared, and it was a match that wasn’t worth there time or will ever stay in their memory.

Now, I’ve had a few good matches with the Phantom, but I can count on my hand how many times it happens. Now I don’t think it should be removed, it is a perfectly valid monster and I think it is quite well balanced for what it is. But perhaps one thought. From my understanding the monster works on player proximity and sound from traps, to footstep and flashlights being turned on and off. We as a player base do not fully understand the Phantom, but perhaps, the proximity effect should be removed, and replaced with an ‘aura’ the Phantom could put up from time to time, anyone in that aura would be detected. This move would need a decent cool down timer so that the Phantom could just not hang out in doorways and spike it whenever. To balance this more if a player springs any trap whatsoever the phantom should be alerted no matter the distance, this would strike fear in the heart of the player not knowing how far the phantom is, but knowing he is now on his way, and they need to calmly, slowly move away. This effect could be done with something on the Phantoms over display, perhaps a pulse that gives off slower intervals far away and faster intervals closer. The trap and the player would have a shimmering outline around it, the trap until the Phantom reached the location and the player the standard time as currently.

I feel as a player the next thing that should be looked at should be the crashing issues, and also allow players to save there log in information and password so on the occasion they do crash, they are not scrambling to enter their information to rejoin their friends.

Once this is corrected I feel that monsters in general should have scaring non damaging moves and abilities with great range to keep the players on edge and fresh. Jump scares are great but if they are used over and over again it loses its effect, think Dead Space. It would be great if for example the lurker could enter a non-damage form, he could see the players but they can’t see him. He could make things move, blood drip from the walls, doors slam as players draw closer to them, fade a players vision to black, move them to another location on the map and then allow them to see again. This games potential is honestly non ending. I feel like this could turn out to be the greatest horror game of the next decade. I wish the game developers much luck and I hope they read all of this, and consider some of what I said.

reviewText:
I'm writing this now, still a little stressed and in the throws of an adrenaline high caused by my friends. First and foremost, play this game with a group of friends who are bad at the game along side you and can get better with you. Playing with randoms online will not help you learn in this HIGH stress environment and the current how-to guides online are only so helpful.

Here's what you get:
You're one of the survivors in the haunted hotel/asylum/hospital, and your on a scavenger hunt for keys to open the various locked doors on the map. As you creep around, you deal with randomly generated hauntings that do aweful things like make the dark screen darker, mysterious spooky noises play in your ear, or keyboard keys can even be disabled. All temporary.
And thats all before your friend takes control of one of three monsters and attempts to murder you before you get the silver key and escape.

The keys and tools are all hidden in obscure places, anything from in drawers of desks to the garbage can in the woods. But never somewhere completly random like the middle of the floor of a ball room. They are hidden well, but not unfairly at all. The rest of the challenge is finding what doors they unlock. Eventually leading out.

The Three Monsters:
As of now there are only three creatures to threaten you and they all garner a different approach to avoid. Here's the long/short;
Lurker sets traps to try to pinpoint your location and materializes in a blink for a few seconds at a time. You pretty much just run from him like an old monster movie. Bracing doors and sobbing until he's gone.

The phantom is 'blind' and only sees players who make a lot of noise. People complain about him being Overpowered but  thats mostly because they run around and get slapped instantly. You need to be sneaking when this ghoul roams the halls.

Then there's mary. She randomly teleports around the map, and if she fills up her spooky-meter she frenzies and can run at you rather than her usual trundle. Think the Witch from Left 4 Dead, popping and locking through the dining room looking for victims.

The Good:
-Very different kind of game play. If you have a group of friends you dont mind never wanting to talk to again, team up and go scavenger hunting.
-This is a HORROR game, not an FPS. When you see the monster you run. There are no guns, just a flashlight. This might sound like a negative, but it really helps amp up the FEAR
-Atmosphere. This might be a little generic, but they really do try to use your less obvious senses to pick up on the creepy factor. You get trained to listen for traps and musical queues, little details, that when you finally do see something. It hits hard and helps you scare.

The Bad
-Crashes. There seems to be a lot of crashes between my friends and I. Hardware capability dont seem to be the issue, and if someone drops midgame, they wont be able to get back in. They'll only be able to spectate.
-Genuine stress level. It might not be a problem to everyone, but I get genuinly stressed out. Legs tight. Hands sweating. Worrying about ever little step. This is why you play with friends. Let the strange monster creeping on you be your pal. Not some mook on teh interwebs.

Final Verdict:
Love it. Go in on a 4 pack with your friends. Maybe hope it winds up on a sale. Hopefully the crashes get patched out and new features like new monsters and  different playable characters get added. But this is not a game I can compare to any other experience very well.

If players could jump back in if they were kicked and the crashes were resolved I would say full price is worth it. As it stands now, $19.99 is a little steep for what feels like early access material. However I still love the experience. And few things are as satisfying as hearing your friends fill their diapers over skype as you pop out around the corner.

body...

reviewText:
This game is terrible.

Its buggy and it’s unbalanced as hell. I’ve played a good amount of this game and have only come close to winning once, and that was because the monster was afk for half the time.
One time I spawned and my camera was just completely flipped for no reason and I had to restart the entire game to get it back to normal.
There are only 3 monsters and half the levels all look exactly the same.

But I play this game anyway, and it’s ♥♥♥♥ing terrifying.

The best word that I can use to describe how this game makes me feel is drained.
The atmosphere is perfect and all the little sounds and visuals add everything you’d need to be scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

There you are, the last one of your friends alive and you have the finals keys clutched in your trembling hands as your flashlight starts to flicker. You know that the exit is somewhere ahead of you but you can’t tell in the dimming light.
The pressure becomes unbearable, worse and worse the closer you get to safety. The sensation makes you feel almost just as insane as the character you’re playing as.
But there it is. The monster jumps out and lunges at you, and in that last moment of bile inducing terror all you can feel is peace.
Serenity.
You know your journey is over and you no longer have to fight.

As your mangled corpse is tossed to the side you’re brought back to the game lobby with your friends vying for a new game.

And you feel drained.


10/10 would ♥♥♥♥ with my emotions again.

reviewText:
I think that this game deserves a honest and detailed review because of all the negative reviews it received. I will try to remedy that, but I will also address the technical difficulties me and four of my friends faced while we were playing. If you are not interested in reading a wall of text, there is a TL;DR version at the bottom so feel free to check that out!


Why do I recommend this game? Because it shocked me and it blew me away. It crushed all of my preconceptions of what is and what can be a good horror game. And here are a few reasons why:
I've never before played a scary co-op horror game.
Never ever. And i honestly thought I never will. Then this game almost made me fall from my chair in one instance and I even wasn't the last person alive. Though, I only recommend playing this game with a group of friends, because playing on public servers can really ruin the experience. Trust me. This game is all about the atmosphere.

Monster design is in my honest opinion superb.
They are given unfair advantages and the developer understands that is the thing that makes them scary.

Game forces players to adapt their tactics and their approach to the level they are facing based on the monster they are playing against.
If you want to add a little bit of additional suspense you can actually play with all random" setting and not check the player list when the game loads to see which monster you are facing. That way actually you really don't know what you can and cannot do. For example. If you are playing against Mary you can run but you should not have your flashlight on. If you're playing against Lurker you don't want to communicate through in game voice because it can hear you. If you are playing against Phantom you absolutely must not run or keep switching on/off your flashlight because you will die almost instantly.

Being a monster is not all about winning and ending a game soon
date: it is about creating the experience for the survivors.\nLet me give you an example - Today we played a hour long game in which we faced Mary (basically the girl from "The Ring") in the old abandoned factory. My heart was racing for the whole hour
recommended: especially when we lost two players and my friend and I were the last ones left. At one instance we actually bumped our faces in the monster player because he had the luck to teleport in front of us. He didn't kill us and just gave us a good scare before teleporting away. Why? Because as the monster you are the "creator" of suspense and fear. Good monster will miss a chance for an easy kill from time to time. He will stalk his prey
hoursPlayed: instill fear into the survivors and create really scary situations. That is why I recommend playing with friends
voteText: because it's not about the winning
helpfulPercent: it's about having the best possible experience. We did all die in the end
votesHelpful: not because of a lucky teleport
votesTotal:
but because of our own mistakes.

Playing against human controlled monster is terrifying.
You can not glitch him out. He has no clear pattern of behaviour you can exploit. He adapts and learns about your patterns of movement and tries to adapt his strategy so he has the biggest chance of finding you. Human intelligence far surpasses any artificial intelligence (AI) and makes this game truly unique. Every one of your friends will have his own way of playing certain monsters.

When you are the last one alive the stakes are raised tenfold and the game really shines.
Other players can spectate you and can hear you talk
votesFunny:
scream and get freaked out. But you are alone and defenceless against the enemy you can only outsmart but you cannot beat.
What do I recommend for the best game experience?There are a few things i reccomend you do as it will vastly improve your game experience:
Use in-game voice chat (automatic voice detection setting turned on) with 3D sound enabled.
While the sound quality is not the best I have ever seen
commentsCount: it gets the job done
column16:
and it really adds to the atmosphere. One monster in particular (Lurker) can use your voice to locate you when he is in his corporeal form. Three-dimensional sound is really well done and it can often help you find your friends. Another neat feature is that you won't be able to hear your friends when you die (it would really ruin it for me if I could hear my friends support me when I am the only one alive)

Play with premade five/four player groups. Do not play with random people!
It ruins the experience to hear monster sing his national anthem in a squeaky voice. As I've said
column17: you need to get into the character because otherwise you won't get the best experience. You need to want to be scared. If you don't have a group of friends that can take the game seriously i advise you not to buy it as you won't get the enjoyment out of it. Even if you don't have the fifth player the game plays just fine with four people.\n\nWhen playing the monster
column18: don't play just to win.\nEverybody likes to win
column19:
but it's your duty to make the game fun for other people. Play to scare. Play to make your friends enjoy this really great game. Toy with them. They will thank you later.

Play on "all random" setting and don't check which monster you are facing.
It raises the stakes and creates permanent suspense.
Technical stuff!Here are our experiences. We DID NOT have major problems with this game so far
column20: but i will update this review if we get more problems down the line - we ran this game on seven systems so far (two of us have laptops) so I can give you somewhat detailed performance breakdown and you can compare these specs to your own specs. Also note that "Film grain setting is OFF across all systems because we simply dislike the effect as it brightens the view.\nGame runs smoothly on my main rig (Nvidia GeForce GTX 295
column21: Intel Core i7 940
column22: 4GB RAM @ 1920x1080) - Stable 60FPS with Shadows on Medium
column28: Depth of Field ON.\n\nGame is playable on my laptop (Nvidia GeForce 635M
column38: Depth of Field OFF.\n\nGame runs smoothly on my friends rig (Nvidia GeForce GTX 770
column40: 8GB RAM @ 1920x1080) - stable 60+FPS on max settings with Film grain OFF.\n\nGame suprisingly runs great on an older rig (Radeon HD5670
column43: 2GB RAM @ 1440x900) - stable 40-50FPS with Shadows on Medium
column49:
Depth of Field OFF.

The only computer that had real issues running this game was an older laptop and even it could run it without crashes.Second part - Game and network stability!
The game did crash a few times but it only once obstructed our game experience. Game tends to crash when switching to full screen
column50:
but a simple game restart fixes it.
We've had almost no problems with network connectivity - game lobby just once froze for me as a game host but it wasn't anything a simple re-host couldn't fix. Game didn't crash while we were playing and we had just one random disconnect (i blame my lousy upload).

TL;DRFour of my friends and I had none of the issues other reviewers pointed out. I've had a lot of fun with this title and would honestly recommend it to you if you have a group of friends that will get into character and won't actively work to ruin the atmosphere. Even though this game has a learning curve it is quite rewarding. Give it a try!"

Damned is one of those games where you play with your friends to be scared with them or to scare them.

Damned has built on the horror genre in it's own unique way; The monster (Currently Lurker" and "Phantom") are player controlled

reviewText:
I should start by saying that the game did provide a few sessions of fun. That being said, there are a number of problems with the game:

1. The premise is very narrow and wears thin quickly. At first it is scary and you die all the time. Then you realise that you cannot possibly complete this game (see point 2) without studying the particulars of the monster you are facing. The minute you do that, the scary aspect pretty much disappears, or in the very least much of it is lost.

2. The game is extremely hard for the survivors. The only way to beat it is to treat it like any other computer game and learn specific strategies... but in a game so dependent on atmosphere and fright, this ruins things.

3. Once you have your strategy in place, studied the monster to the point where there is nothing scary about it, and are ready to play, you will soon find the game becoming very repetitive and tedious. You will essentially wander around in the dark trying to find that one damn key that no one could find to the door that is still locked. After 20 minutes of going around in the same circle doing nothing but trying to imagine where on earth you forgot to look and you will be ready to pull your hair clean off your head.

4. The door opening and closing mechanism is moronic. You will not believe how moronic it is if you did not try it.

All in all, not a game I would recommend. Interesting idea, but not very well executed and also lacking in content to make it interesting in the long run.
voteText: 160 of 258 people (62%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Damned is a 4 vs 1 cooperative game where 4 survivors are trapped inside a location such as an asylum, hospital, or hotel trying to escape the horror that lies within. In order to escape, keys must be located and boards must be removed to open the final exit door all while avoiding a deadly monster. There are 4 different types of monsters that a group can play against. Each monster has its own unique abilities to locate and kill the survivors and each survivor has a different set of attributes. This leads to a lot of cat and mouse tactics in knowing where to look and when to run and hide.

There's about 10 different maps, a few different game modes, and key placement is randomized each game.

The game has a small learning curve which involves each monster's playing strategy to efficiently locate and kill the survivors, and as a survivor understanding where keys typically are hidden and learning to avoid and escape each monster. It is a very satisfying game after learning the fundamentals, but until that point I felt kind of lost.

There are typically a handful of games going although it is often difficult to find a public game because the game has a very small player base and the majority of games available are private. You may also have to wait several minutes for a spot to open up or people to join your game, but if you already have a small group of friends that won't be a problem.

reviewText: I can understand the positive reviews. There is the promise of a good game here, which promises to be a lot of fun with friends. It's just not that playable at the moment. The game should not have been released in its current state, since it is glitchy to the point of being impossible to play. Your game will crash, your voice chat will not work, you will be unable to connect, you won't be able to perform certain actions, etc. (At one point, I asked if it was still in beta, because it's absolutely unacceptable as a final version.) Even if those glitches were fixed, there are some serious design flaws. The stages are extremely dark and murky, which may create an atmosphere but makes it hard to see the tiny items that the survivors need. This decision might be okay if the game wasn't already so imbalanced. The survivors don't have enough options to get away from or defend themselves from the ghost, who has a one-hit kill. They also aren't given any indications about what keys open what doors, so it becomes an exercise in trying every key in every door. Worst of all, the ghost and the survivors are in the same voice chat, which makes it impossible to coordinate with the other survivors without the ghost hearing all your plans and knowing where you will be. So, in its current form, I cannot recommend it to others.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Is it buggy? Hell yeah, this is an alpha afterall.

Is it fun? Dear God, yes.

This is one of the most tense and dynamic experiences I've had playing a game with friends in forever. There's is something so heart-poundingly terrifying about being hunted by a living, breathing monster that cannot be fooled with AI pathing tricks. It WILL find you because it thinks just like you; therefore you cannot, MUST NOT, think like you. Pure genius.

It took a couple games/crashes and some trial and error to find what works and what doesn't. But half a dozen games in, our schoolgirl giggling chatter evolved into concise, razor sharp planning. It has layers of depth to it as you get better, both for the survivors and the monster. I cannot recommend Damned more highly.

reviewText:
I never thought that an online/coop game can be scary. I was wrong.

Haven't had the chance yet to play as a monster (only played a few rounds), but playing as a survivor is awesome. It is like playing Amnesia or Outlast withoutt the hiding in wardrobes but with 3 other people but you don't know where they are, there are no indicators. If you see them, good, but you can lose track of them if you don't pay attention or wander off. The maps are quite large with lots of rooms and corridors so it is also a good thing.

When you are walkign around and suddenly see a sobbing, slowly walking girl in the corner of your eyes, or a ghost flying around which can only see you if you make noise and then you accidently activate a trap by walking past it, you know you are probably dead.

Your objective is to collect keys, combinations for safes, hammers/crowbars for barricades and find the exit zone, which can be anywhere (I guess it is random, in one of my rounds it was a random small cell).

It also makes it more fun that you cannot run from the monsters, most you can hope for is that you can outsmart/outrun them but even then you only win a little time till they can enter into physical/attack form again. The fact that the monter is controlled by a player makes it more fun, more random. Some people like to hunt everyone down as soon as they can while others prefer to play with the survivors and go after them one by one (I like it when I get this one against me).

Now the cons:
The game does seem to need a bit more polishing, it doesn't seem to optimized but , while I can run Outlast on maximum settings, I have to leave this game on medium to get 30+ fps which is weird.
Also, I hope they will keep adding monsters (some slenderman-type would be fun or perhaps one that can mimic the form of a survivor to deceive them etc.).
Later, some additional maps would be nice.

At the moment I can recommend the game if you like horror, want to try something new (I haven't experienced this kind of online scary coop fun before) and if your machine can handle it. If your answer is no to either of these, perhaps you should wait a bit. As far as I know, this game has been on for a while but only gotten to Steam recently, I hope it will make it more popular and they can keep on improving the game from the income.

TL;DR: The game is fun, new, scary but not really optimized.

reviewText:
Good reviews, promising gameplay-videos, awesome design of game (4 good guys vs 1 enemy, all 5 are player-controlled), but you need friends to play this.
Players in public hosted games usually leave very fast and don't join back (this could be caused by crashes), and hardly anyone joins public games.

I recommend this to people who have 4 actively playing friends to have fun with in this kinda game, but otherwise: Don't buy it, you won't be able to play much.


Once in a game (although that is tough luck playing with strangers), it's fun!
Suvivors have to play together to leave the level before the monster gets them, and the game is a good scare! (no blood&gore kind of horror, the creeping kind of horror)

The monster, being invincible and killing any player in one hit, does have an unfair advatage, although it does make playing together more important and more fun, and the monster could tease the players for fun.


Summary: This is amazing with 4 friends and you (5 total), it sucks in a public game.

reviewText:
Invite your friends and play this awesome horror game! You’ll be playing as human or monster, total of 5 players for each session (4 Survivors and 1 monster).

Four people is trapped with a monster, the survivors main objective is to find the way-out.
Do you have what it takes to get all the survivors out while seeing ghostly things, hearing noises or desperately running from a monster, who’s only desire is to hunt down and kill you and your friends?

The monster will be able to assume ethereal form, which to hunt the survivors, set up traps that trigger noises and events. Also assume physical form, which allows the monster to kill you, also toggle a rage mode which almost always ends with a killing spree.

Sum up with: One of the most enjoyable horror multiplayer games I have ever played, surprisingly addicting if you’re in for a spooky treat with your friends.
Damned is a masterpiece and worth a try and I can assure you will be screaming!

reviewText:
E: This review was written a day before the July 28th update.

Hello~ as of this review, I've clocked 62 hours on Damned.

The reason why I'm giving this game a thumbs down will become apparent quite quick.

I'm not going to give overviews, so I apologize in advance if anything sounds off to someone who knows nothing about the game just yet. Simply put, despite how much fun I have with the game, a lot of my friends DON'T have fun, and I'm going to list all of the problems here.

1. The insanity system is bogus. E: This has been fixed as of July 28th, about two days after I wrote this review.

Seriously. Having so many bad effects happen throughout the game is annoying, and un-needed unless you happen to be playing against Mary (because she moves slow enough to warrant them). Late in a game, survivors see things that aren't there, but still physically affect them, turning them blind, slowing them down, or making them deaf; often all at once. This seriously needs to become an optional thing, but for now, it's extremely crippling to any survivors that manage to last long enough against monsters to begin with.

2. Mary's teleporting is bogus. - E: Still a problem, unfortunately.

Tonight I've had a game where Mary's teleported into the same general area 5 times, sometimes right next to where she was previously, successfully edging survivors closer to their spawn point with no way to progress. This speaks for herself: Mary's teleportation mechanism is NOT random, but is more biased to teleporting into the same room despite how big a map is, and needs a system countermeasure.

3. Phantom's camping is bogus. E: Still a problem, unfortunately.

This one speaks for itself. Phantom needs a penalty for staying in one place (sometimes to camp a corpse or deliberately trap survivors) for too long. Otherwise, he's fine. Applies to a lesser extent to the Lurker as well.

Those are the three big issues that my friends tend to have with this game. Personally, I've beat the odds and have continued playing despite these major flaws, and can still manage to have fun in the game to this day. And these problems don't even touch the plethora of other problems, such as...

- Frequent client crashes
- Host disconnecting from a game crashes the game
- Connection issues cause duplicates of corpses to walk continuously into walls
- Maps such as the factory spawning unwinnable for the survivors due to key placement
- Lack of care / content / fixes from the developers (E: As of 1/30/16, it appears as if they've deleted their community forum)

So with that being said, I definitely cannot recommend this game, since it's nowhere close to being worth its full $20 pricetag. Know that if you do end up buying this game, whether it's for the full price or on a sale, that you'll be paying lazy developers that are more talk and less action. If you can somehow see past that and can see a glimmer of fun trapped deep within the potential that is Damned, then I shall see you there.

Oh, and don't forget. The monsters can kill you in one hit. But I don't have a problem with that. I just want to actually SEE the monster kill me instead of getting blinded before the climax. What kind of a climax is that?

E: Having the ability for people to change their usernames was a bad addition, so I'm not going to be changing the recommendation of my review. The game's files are predominately client-sided and can be edited by hackers. Now the hackers in the game can change their names, and we'll never know who we're playing against anymore, so thanks a lot 9heads.

reviewText:
Damned has the potential to be a good game. Unfortunately there are some...damning...problems...heh..heh...Okay I'll get serious.

Damned is a 5 player COOP game. 4 players versus 1 monster. The player's goal is to escape, while the monster's goal is to kill them. The players goal consists of running around the map looking for keys to unlock doors until you get the required items to leave through the escape(A hammar or a crowbar, and the Silver Key). The monster has to kill all the survivors before they escape. Sounds easy right? Well currently there are 3 monsters, and they are pretty balanced in my opinion. Of course, you can be a ♥♥♥♥ and just kill everyone off the bat on certain maps, if you know what you're doing, but that's no fun. It's way better to play it smart and try to scare the players rather than just kill them. And holy ♥♥♥♥ is this game scary. I didn't think a multiplayer game could be scary but I was wrong. The way the monsters are designed and the atmosphere of the levels make this a very tense experiance.

Sounds good right? Unfortunatly the game is buggy. It was an Early access title, but for some reason they decided it was ready for full release.

The game runs at 25-60 FPS on my rig(Specs below), up and down constantly depending on where I am and what I'm looking at. It can be very distracting and take me out of the game. Sometimes the game will just lock to 30FPS and you have to restart your computer to fix it. No idea why, devolopers haven't explained it, they just gave the solution.

I host most of the games with my friends because I have the better connection(105Megabit down, 20Megabit up), but that doesn't stop the game from lagging. Normally in other games when someone hosts something they don't lag locally, but the people connecting to him will. Not in this game, everybody feels it, sometimes the game will just freeze for no reason. This game runs off of 9Heads servers(They are located in Brazil), meaning you have to create an account, and log in from within the game. That means whenever something happens to their servers, you can't play the game.

Now, the most damning problem my friends and I run into when trying to run this game happens before the game even starts. We all get in a lobby, select our favorite characters, select a map, start it up. Host loads in just fine, waiting for other players. The other players get to the screen that says Waiting for the host to start the game" only...they haven't really loaded...they're still loading(At least I hope that's what's going on)
date: but for some reason they show that screen and their game is frozen. They can't do anything until it finally loads. Loading times can be anywhere from 10 seconds to 5 minutes. We're so used to this that we routinely ask if anyone is frozen when we start the game. "I'm good" "I'm good" "Frozen..." "Alright let's wait..." When the player can finally press TAB and see the player list
recommended: they've loaded in and we can start playing.\n\nThe devolopers are kind of active on the forum. They try to help people with problems but they aren't permenant solutions
hoursPlayed: problems always come back. They say they're working on an update
voteText: but don't have an ETA on when. Only "This year". At the time of writing this review(2/19/2015) we haven't gotten an update since November 5th
helpfulPercent: 2014. And the only planned update for 2015 is a "new monster" Nothing else. The devolopers are not native english speakers and are few in numbers. I feel as if game devolopment is a side project to their real life activities

reviewText:
So, after date night with the wife on Halloween(we saw Annabelle, fairly creepy) I on impulse bought this as it was A.) Seemed creepy B.) Let me play as a monster C.) Was on sale.

I'm glad I did, because Damned, low budget that it surely is, is pretty much what I'd want in a multiplayer horror game. The environments are creepy, the monsters all play quite different and it's pretty easy to get spooked as one of the survivors. This is also one of those games that I think is best played with friends.

Currently there are ten maps, all variations on scary locales. A few asylums, a couple of hotels, a warehouse, some sort of factory, and a restaurant(of all things). Survivor's currently have 4 characters to choose from, but really it's just an aesthetic choice. Monsters have 3 character's to choose from:
The blind Phantom.
The phasing Lurker.
Sobbing Mary(my personal favorite).The Phantom can only see players if they make noise or it gets close enough to them, the Lurker phases in and out of reality, only able to track players by setting traps, and Mary must slowly approach while being teleported randomly, until she can let out a scream and sprint right upon her victims.

Having said all of that, I do have a few issues with it:

Playing as the survivor is much more challenging than playing as one of the monsters, to such a degree that picking any of the monster choices seems like a guaranteed win. The map variety also seems a little lacking. The largest issue however is will crash a little too often for my taste or require you to CTRL+ALT+DLT and end process.

All in all, I'd say it's worth what it's currently priced and good solid fun.

reviewText:
Damned is a 5 player horror game.  There are two playable roles in the game: the humans, and the monster.  It's a pretty great idea they have here.  As humans, you have to try and escape.  There's 4 different humans you can choose to play as, but it doesn't really matter which you choose.  You start with nothing but a flashlight and need to search for batteries, as well as keys and other things that can help you escape the monster.  Navigate the very dark buildings and try to get out quickly, because eventually you start to see and hear things in game and when you run out of batteries it's a lot harder.  As the monster, your goal is to kill all the humans.  There are currently 3 available monsters to play as: Bloody Mary, the Lurker, and the Phantom.  Each one has some advantages as well as some handicaps and they each play very differently.

I will get the negatives out of the way.  This game has some pretty bad bugs that hopefully will be fixed soon.
- You can lose connection to the match for no reason (at least on your end).
- The lobby might not recognize you have joined, and won't include you in the game when it is started.  You may have to back out and rejoin a few times, or have the host restart the lobby, for it to work.
- Sometimes the game won't allow you to choose which human/monster you want to play, even though the lobby allows you to choose.
- Every once in awhile the main menu from the start of the game, will pop up over the game while you are playing.  You can still play while it's up, but you can't exit it and after that happens when you talk in chat your name won't show up.
-When you are killed, sometimes your corpse will still be standing.  Sometimes it will even walk into walls and will still let you spectate it.

These bugs are very annoying, but the game is still incredibly fun.  Get a group of friends and hop in.  Some will say it's a very scary game, some will say it isn't at all.  What is and isn't scary is very subjective really and will differ for everyone.  For me personally, it has had some pretty scary moments but a lot of the time it just gets really tense.  If you're playing with friends you can have some really hilarious moments too.  The idea of this game is pretty genius and it is definitely worth picking up, though if you can get it on sale that'd be good.

reviewText:
I'm totally in love with the concept behind this game, and while it can be clunky and rough at times, it succeeds in being an actually scary multiplayer experience that offers a unique kind of fun you won't find elsewhere.

While this is a recommendation, there are several things I should note before you make your purchase:
- $20 is quite high for the amount of content currently in the game, and updates seem to be coming rather slowly. The developers have not yet abandoned the project, but they are a small, inexperienced team. This may be better as a sale purchase if you're uncertain.
- There are a high amount of technical issues in the current build. Many players report unplayable, slideshow framerates no matter how powerful their rig, though this sometimes randomly resolves itself through reinstallation or other fiddling. There are also occasional crashes that can ruin a match. I've only had one so far after several hours of play, but it's still frustrating. Thankfully, host migration is fairly seamless.
- The playerbase is fairly small at the moment. While it's possible to fill up a lobby with random players, and there are generally a small handful of public servers running at any given time, you're much better off having a consistent group of friends to play this with.

With all that said, I'm having a ton of fun with this game and it just comes down to the great idea and clever design behind it. The levels are all creepy, dark abandoned buildings like hospitals, asylums (lots of asylums), hotels, a factory, etc. The monsters themselves all have unique mechanics that require patience and vigilance from both the human and monster players. They're all deadly and can take out a survivor in a single blow, but have some sort of limitation on when they can attack, or how they move, or even how they see. It means that even as players become more experienced, the battle of wits and does he know that I know that he knows..." mindgames make for exciting matches. Despite the competitive nature of the game
date: there isn't a big emphasis on the competition and it's more about having fun. The monster player has to be very very patient
hoursPlayed: aggressive players out of the game.\n\nThe simple requirement for the survivors to explore and find keys keeps things active and prevents extended campfests

reviewText:
After having played a fair few games of this, I can pretty easily say two things about this.
ONE: Do not let my thumbs up fool you, this is not a game I recommend for the weak of heart and mind. This game was released majorly unfinished, and is still very clearly meant to be in a testing phase. Frequent crashes, a command prompt opened up upon play, and frequent glitches plague this game.
TWO: Do not let one fool you either, by no means is this a bad game, and has a pretty excellent concept behind it with a fair enough execution.

As far as I am concerned, the largest two issues with this game are this:
-Lack of lots of testing and polishing that allow this game to truly shine.
-Lack of content to add variation, such as a larger list of monsters to truly vary up the gamplay.

This game is very rough as it is, and could certainly do with some well-needed polish, which, thankfully, the devs are providing. However, I feel the most necessary implementation (after polish, of course) would be Steam Workshop support, allowing the devs to iron out kinks while the community works to try and make some monsters, levels, and even seperate game modes themselves.

However, I still enjoy the game, and I feel that anyone with enough friends willing to play it (three at the very least, don't play public games) would find amount of enjoyment in this clever little horror game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of October 15, 2013:

Fun game when it actually works.  Very frustrating 90% of the time, however.
Here's why:

1) 50% chance of the game crashing upon loading into a server.
2) It's like winning the lottery if you and a friend connect without one of you crashing.
3) Everytime you crash, you must re-enter your username and password (very annoying).
4) All maps have a chance of keys not spawning properly which makes it impossible for survivors to win.
5) Asylum map is currently bugged and unbeatable as survivors.
6) If the monster goes afk, the game isn't challanging.
7) If a survivor goes afk with a key in his inventory, the rest of the survivors are ♥♥♥♥ed until the monster kills him (there's no votekick either).
8) If the host ragequits in the middle of the game, everyone gets kicked.

I'll update this review if and when the game gets fixed.

reviewText:
In its current state, I cannot recommend this game. The game is riddled with bugs and there are not many servers that actually have players in them, which is bad since the game is only multiplayer.

I have only managed to play one game with four other people and the experience was actually pretty fun, but this does not happen often. The idea of the game is actually really great, but the game itself is buggy and sometimes unresponsive. The mechanic for opening and closing doors is a bit clunky as well and sometimes it can even be frustrating.

If you do plan on getting this game, make sure some of your friends are getting it or have it already and get it during a sale. If your friends do not have the game it will be extremely challenging to actually play the game the way it is meant to be played.

Overall, it is not a terrible game, but it suffers from a lack of a playerbase and it has a good amount of bugs.

reviewText:
10/10 would die with a scream in my throat, insanity-blurred vision, and pee running down my leg again.

Alternatively,

10/10 would whisper creepy nonsense to the scurrying humans while hunting them through an asylum again.

Really though, it could still use some polish. Getting everyone loaded into lobbies properly needs a bit of work, the mechanic for opening doors is often frustrating (though that adds to the tension) and there's really no hand holding, but after 2 hours of play with some friends I was getting the hand of both sides and it had my pulse racing like no other game in recent memory.

reviewText:
I was pleasantly surprised by Damned. The gameplay does get repetitive, and eventually you get tired with the constant issue of starting a game, only to have 1 or 2 people disconnect and not be able to join back.

The game is fun if you have 4-5 friends to play with. When I say friends, I mean friends you can talk to and communicate with. My friends and I would have the humans all in a group call and then the monster on their own. This made the game pretty damn fun, as we could communicate.

The gameplay gets pretty boring after 9-10 hours of playing. You basically run around looking for keys while avoiding the monster. Each monster has different abilities, meaning you have to change your strategy slightly depending on the type of monster. Currently, there are only 3 monsters.

The Lurker - The Lurker has a physical and nonphysical form. In its non-physical form, it cannot see players and players cannot see it, but it can place traps. Traps make a loud noise, notifying The Lurker where the humans are. The Lurker can then transform into physical form (if it has enough charged up) and try and kill them.

Mary - Mary moves very very slow, and Mary can see humans and humans can see Mary. Mary has the ability to teleport when charged up (also randomly teleporting if you do not for a long time). Mary also slowly gains Frenzy". Frenzy mode allows Mary to run faster than survivors and kill them. To charge Frenzy
date: you have to get close to a survivor. The closer you are
recommended: the faster it charges up.\n\nThe Phantom - This one is personally my least favorite. The survivors can see the Phantom at all times
hoursPlayed: but the Phantom cannot see the humans unless they make a noise. If a survivor begins sprinting
voteText: the Phantom will hear loud music and that survivor will be able to be seen through walls. You also can't turn your flashlight on and off when the Phantom is around. Basically
helpfulPercent: the closer you get to the Phantom
votesHelpful: the less sound you have to make
votesTotal:
by crouching or walking.

reviewText: This game could have been really interesting however after a couple of games I have to say its utterly boring.  After you get over the initial scares there isn't a huge amount to keep you coming back.  I don't mind the graphics and I can handle the dark levels.  When I first played the game opening the doors while a beast was chasing me led to semi squirts of urine pumping down my trouser legs but after a few games it just becomes frustrating rather than terrifying.  I find that the monsters are overpowered and tend to camp dead  bodies (which is the only place you will find certain keys).  The levels are not large enough to really run away or hide in, making it easy for the overpowered monster to find you.  Maybe if they release a sequel it could be good but this game in its current format needs work.

reviewText:
This game is a great game to play with friends.  It is very fun being a monster, moreso when you mess with the survivors rather than trying to kill them every chance you get.  Playing as a survivor will get your heart racing and wake your roomates.  The ambiance adds a serious chill to the air as you desperately look for items to aid in the escape, all the while being on your toes looking out for the monster.  Swinging your mouse to open doors and cabinets like the Penumbra games gives you more control, and more chances to make mistakes trying to slam doors on chasing monsters.  Sounds like a game to give a whirl right?


Not so fast.


You might want to rethink that purchase.  This game is absolutely loaded with problems, mainly with nuances in the design and the framework of the game itself.  Right off the bat, this game is written in Python, meaning you will have to install Python first, however Damned will install Python for you.  After installation you may have to restart your computer to fix any initial problems you run into.  Restarting a machine to get a video game to work is unacceptable in this day and age.  This game is not optimized very well.  High shadows, lighting, or AA will tax some machines more than it should with unremarkable differences in the quality of the graphics.  Connection issues can be spontaneous, and freezing can at some times be common.  This game has moods.  One day it will work relatively fine, the next it won't.  Hope you like verifying your game files, because you will be doing that a lot with this game, and you will almost always find at least one file missing.  Even after reacquiring that missing file your game may still not work properly.  It's not uncommon to spend more time than should be necessary just to get everyone to join the game proper.

This game has horrible balancing issues.  The monsters are quite powerful, with some maps making it just downright impossible to win as survivors.  There are no limits to setting traps as the monsters, and there are loads of things that can be trapped.  Many maps have narrow corridors with overhanging lights that can be trapped and impossible to avoid.  Survivors also have no way of knowing what is trapped without springing it.  In order for the survivors to win, they must find the silver key, hammer/crowbar, and the actual escape door, all while avoiding the monster.  The key and tools however are usually behind some locked door which requires some other key to open.  Of course there is no indication of what keys open what, with some levels having many locked doors and you will find yourself running back and forth looking in every nook and cranny for every key you can find and testing them on many doors until you can open one.  Insanity, the condition set upon survivors as the game drags on, is designed to keep survivors moving, but uses cheap jump scares and annoying hands to do the job.  Also darkens the screen or flickers the flashlight sometimes which is actually nice.  The maps are dreary, abandoned, gritty, dark places, a staple of horror.  But they can also be confusing and tedious, especially when trying to find that one key to open that one door.  Of the 11 maps, 3 are in an asylum.  Sometimes items may glitch out and cant be picked up, or cabinet doors that's shouldn't be locked won't open.  There are also jack-o-lanterns all over the place.  Is this a halloween or horror game?


Even after all this, I would still recommend the game if not for one thing:  The asking price.  $20 USD is highway robbery for a game in as bad a state as this.  Maybe the developers believe they put in effort worthy of selling for $20.  I don't see it.


Buy this game?  No.  Sit on it.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game seems awesome, and is a lot of fun when it actually works. Unfortunately it's riddled with bugs, and often downright unplayable.

Often on launch you can't actually click anything, and when joining servers (or loading back into a lobby after a game) you may not actually load in. Both of these bugs require restarting the game until you get lucky and it works. There are bugs during gameplay as well; several times my friends and I have encountered keys simply floating in the air but they can't be grabbed.

I'm amazed this game is considered launched". It's the quality I expect from a beta or Early Access game."

reviewText: So here's the scoop, don't pay full price for this game because you'll immediately regret it and probably refund it. But if you get it on sale, you're more likely to stick with it. Probably the first 10 hours I put into this game were horrible. It crashed all the time, and when I was in game I didn't know what the heck I was doing. Now after 330+hours of this game, I can say it's one of the most fun games I've played. There are bugs with it and it rarely gets updated which is frustrating but I've met many people through this game, one of them is my best friend now. The maps don't change, the monsters don't change but every game is something different. So if you're looking for a fun horror game, get this when it's on sale. Add me if you want someone to play with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well my first opnion when loading up this game was what you would expect from a early release ... But after playing for a while i have to say for £5.99 Its by far one of the most scary PC games i have played ... One momment your walking along looking around for keys the next your running / hideing from the Lurker ! I think the scare/horror factor comes from knowing the Lurker (Enemy) is controlled by a actual person there for you know that they will be even more unexpected ... It has a few gltiches here and there but as i said its a early release and i have to say im impressed :) 4/5 ... if u like horror and a horrible atmosphere and its kind of like Amnesia but with multiplayer then you need to buy this game !

Thanks For Reading hope to see you in there

reviewText:
Got it through Humble Bundle, so it was cheap as dirt, but even dirt can be too expensive at times.

The game is horribly optimized, as it FPS-lagged like hell for me and the random people I was playing with. Moving the camera with the mouse was unbearably laggy and, without any better words to describe it, 'twitchy'. This would lead to deaths and getting stuck in spectator mode, which in turn bugged out only allowing watching the game from the death camera of another player.

From what I understand it's basically an item-finding game, where you walk around a map looking for very small items that you can use to progress to the end of the level. Even without the monster to harrass you all the time, it's very hard, tedious and sadly also very boring. The premise wears out very quick, as it's basically just another Slender clone with new monsters and a multiplayer mode built on top.

In the small amount of time I played the game I got it to crash 6 times, mostly when joining a server and getting stuck in the Waiting for host to start the game" screen.

I can't see anyone paying 20€ (or actually paying any sort of money) for this in its current state
recommended: get it now while it's on Humble Bundle for the average price of the pack. Or
hoursPlayed: much rather
voteText: don't. It's not worth it."

reviewText:
2/10
good concept but the negatives weigh out the positives by a ton.
positives are that it is a good concept, good idea, and the monster ideas are a good touch.
The negatives far outweigh those though.
---
-Let's start with the fact that I could not even sign in.  Every single time I boot the game up I have to restart the entire game (exit the game completely) at least 3-4 times.  Half the time when i go to log it, it says that I can't log in because my account is in use by someone else.  Eventually I could log in, but the problems don't end there.
I tried joining his game, but half the time just joining his game it was broken to where I joined his lobby, but neither of us were actually there and we couldn't start it.  That requires me restarting 3 or 4 times.
-I first tried playing as the phantom with my friend on a one on one match.  Eventually after floating around for half an hour I asked him if he could see where I was, because the survivors should be able to see the phantom, but not the other way around.  I lined his sight up so he would be able to see me, but in his game I was not present. (I would know, I'm sitting right next to him)
-From what I could tell the lurker seemed to be fine from my experience.
-Mary, oh mary, where do I even start?
--I played Mary and I literally could not play her.
--The first game I played i was trapped in a room, so I teleported out, normal right?  Well then I tried to teleport out again and it never let me teleport again that game.  I was literally stuck in that small room with no escape.
--Eventually we started up a new game and I did the same thing, except I teleported into a larger room the second game.  I was walking around for half an hour while my friend walked around the map figuring it out.  Eventaully he said he just got scared because he saw me...except I never left the main room I was stuck in..  I looked over at his screen and my character was moonwalking in his room and then randomly teleported out.  So I asked him if he could walk into the room where i was stuck.  Apparently that room that I was stuck in was one he had also been walking around for 20 minutes as well.  He literally could not see me, and i could not see him (I'm still playing as mary at this point), and all the doors that were open for him, were still closed for me, which is why I never knew he was there.
--We booted it back up (after me restarting three or four times) and i tried Mary one more time.  Except this time I did nothing.  I did not move from the starting location from where I spawned in on the map as Mary.  I then went to his screen and watched him, hoping to help him find my room to simply see if I was there.  But not only did he not find me, a random mary once again was in his game and teleported right in front of him and was moonwalking.  Obviously this both freaked us out!  Except...I'm supposed to be Mary walking around....and my Mary never moved from her starting spot.  At that point I just turned the game off. (yes all of these games I am in his game/player list currently playing)
All in all this game is not worth the time most likely unless it is fixed in a major way.  This game is in now way worth 20 dollars especially in this state.  I'm dissapointed that I paid for this, as it was not a wise purchase from what I could tell.
Buy this at your own risk, as it is broken beyond all belief atm.  If anyone has any help to give me, I'd love to hear it, as I would love for this game to work, but as of now, it's impossible for me to play.

reviewText:
I've played this game on and off since about the summer of 2014 when it was early access. It was a buggy, unoptimized mess. It could barely be played despite the lack of graphics and...really, anything in the game. It would crash constantly on the simplest things.

It is now the summer of 2015, and on first loadup I found that not much has changed. Among the multiple bugs I encountered, one was that I couldn't reach my graphics panel without minimizing, then shrinking the window. The moust simply would not move over on the window, it became locked in place. Then when I clicked on the graphics options, the game crashed.

I reloaded the game. Crashed before it started.

I reloaded the game again. It loaded! I started up a test game to see how it would run, and it finally runs well! So yay for optimization! Then I joined a real game and it crashed on startup.

2/10 due to unplayability. If I could actually play it it would easily be an 8/10. I will edit this review if they ever fix these bugs.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI would love to recommend this game, but I cannot. It has a brilliant premise, and is very creepy with it's stalking monsters and malicious spirits. But it has several catastrophic problems that render it next to unplayable. It is incredibly laggy (and not to do with my connection, which is ultra-fast on all other things I do) and suffers from FPS stuttering to quite a bad degree. Sometimes when survivors die a copy of them stays around, walking endlessly on the air until they are killed as well, leaving two corpses. It has other weird, glitchy bugs like this and I find it difficult to want to play combined with the lag and framerate crawl. It needs a lot of work, to clean up the bugs and made it a smoother game. I wouldn't recommend it until those bugs are ironed out and the game runs smoothly. I give it a 3 out of 10.

reviewText:
Well to put it simply the game is good, but it's not quite Carling.

I have given the game a positive review because in it's current state i would say that it is quite playable for all there are a few bugs with the game give or take.

For instance there are a few irritating ones with the menu's and the lobbies. The player will get a message 'The servers are down/disconnected' Or the player might get stuck in a lobby, unable to join a game or accept invites.

In-game there are not that many bugs i have encountered myself, although there is the odd random floating pumpkin here and odd floating non interactable keys there [Since the games objective is to gather keys this may or may not have an affect on the experience]. The game is currently quite stable.

The game is labeled as a 'Horror'. And it isn't that bad of a one. I can compare the game slightly to that of Slender Man, only it being 5 player online and you don't collect pages you collect keys. With three monsters to choose from and an interacial gang of meddling kids that need to escape from a spooky house or forest before Jim can 'Fix-em'. The game is quite promising.

Although the game doesn't quite have that real 'I just ♥♥♥♥ my pants' feel, it will give you quite a few jumps scares and a mild heart attack every now and then. [Well... Unless it's Mary, then you will probably need to go and change.]

So all in all it is quite a good Horror. And looks like it could develop into something quite good.

If i could rate this Half & Half i would, but i'm going to stick with the positive for now.

reviewText:
Survivarl. Horror. Co-op.

Any one of those words would typically be enough to make me avoid a game.
However, I was invited to play by some friends, and I'm glad I gave it a chance.

This game is a LOT of fun.
When playing with a group of friends, playing as either the monster or the survivors, either way it's a lot of fun.

The diversity of the monsters keeps things interesting as well.
Many levels keeps things feeling fresh.

Some levels can feel fairly claustrophobic, and keys can be super hard to find.
but I suppose that can add to the charm and experience of the game.

At the end of the day, I played for several hours today, was freaking out over thinking I saw a monster when I ddin't, and getting killed constantly. But it was one of the most fun I've had in a long time. Well done!

reviewText: I don't understand how the game managed to get so much positive reviews as it is one of the worst piece of crap I ever played. I'm not talking about the game itself, which looks very good actually, but this is so full of bugs and so badly optimised it is almost unplayable. I got 30 fps with a 770GTX, an I7 3770 CPU and 16Go of ram! And that's with VSync disabled. I'm forced to launch the game multiple times to play because the menu will fail randomly, either because it will freeze on the login screen, or because the mouse cursor won't move (or become invisible! It's like a Kinder surprise but with bugs). And I only cited here a small fraction of the huge pile of bugs this game contains, but it would be far too long to make a complete list here, and it would not be exhaustive as I'm discovering a new major bug everytime I TRY to play!\n\nIf constant fighting against bugs, frequent restarts and jerky framerate is not a problem for you, then you'll probably love this game. But in my opinion, its botched development totaly ruin its potential (using Python for a game? Seriously?).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really fun MULTIPLAYER horror game. There aren't that many multiplayer horror games, specially ones that are as fun as this.
Think of it as Slenderman multiplayer combined with Amnesia the Dark descent.

As a survivor you try to find keys to unlock different doors in the particular map, with the goal of eventually escaping. It's a group effort and when a player dies he/she drops the collected keys that someone has to grab again.

As the monster you try to find and kill the survivors. There are several different monsters which all have they advantages and disadvantages. The monster is limited to what he can see, so it is pretty balanced in that sense.

It is just fun to play this with friends and scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of them or be scared by a friend.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Its an game that with some time and money is going to be one hell of a game,

First of the idea of an Human controlled monster is absolutely epic, when in your every horror game ever, you know what the monster is and how it is coded, to what it reacts to, in here its different, you can know the mechanics of the monsters like one review suggested, but the human aspect of how the person plays the monster is different.

I scared the crap out of my friends by playing very unpredictable, ie; they saw me and knew i would do some crazy ♥♥♥♥, but i didnt, i just remembered the exact spot where they were and surprised them from a different direction, one of the post's suggested that you know what to do with each monster, this is the part where you come along, you can kill the survivers sometimes easily, but hey, whats the fun in that when you can do it so unpredictable causing jumpscares.

Youre the monster, You decide what you do, and how you are going to do it.

That was mostly for one of the earlier review's.

All in all the game is not complete yet, with alot of FPS problems, Login problems, Connection problems, but i can forgive those, for this one will be a gem once it's edges have been smoothed.

For now it has also problems with the maps being too similar, so there is not a large enough map creator implemented in the game, so it gets abit repeatitive, i wish they will add a bigger map generator system at some point, and would not hurt to have a few more monsters, 2/3 of the current ones im loving, 1 of them is not so much of a spooky one but more like ''i see it, i avoid it''..

But as this is an indie game id give this an rating of 10/10 in indie's
compared to big studio games id give this one a 6/10
if the changes and fixes i suggested will be implemented its gonna be atleast a 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A unique and fun horror game. Play as the monster and scare the crap out of other gamers/your friends, or play as the survivor and be scared the crap out of as a Lurker spawns in front of you, a Phantom glides by you, or you start to hear the faint cries of Bloody Mary. This game, although buggy (it's still in development), is a fun one that I keep coming back to you. It's simple but effective horror, and without all the disgusting gore and themes of Silent Hill or the like.

TL;DR If you like BEING SCARED or SCARING OTHER PEOPLE, buy this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For the amount of positives this game brings, there are a few dozen negatives that still lurk and cause this game to be frustrating at times.

Try to not to let that put you off, rest assured, Damned is one of a few games that allows you to enjoy and have a great time with friends, all while mantaining that fear, paranoia, and spine chilling experince.

Yes, the game crashes a lot. There is also a few other bugs which at times stops you from playing at all. But if you can ignore that, you'll really start to love this game. The new update has done so much for this game as well. While the Lurker and Phantom are great, Mary may just be one of the creepiest characters I have ever come up against. The constant paranoia of wondering where she is, the fear of knowing she may appear next to her at any second, and the insanity system that adds a whole new factor too.

I have had some great times with friends on this game, I certainly suggest playing with friends over playing on your own. Overall, I give this an 8/10. The bugs and crashes hold this game back from being a 10!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is actually pretty fun. Bear in mind this is early access and a lot of things may change. The game is great, it has some flaws but thats ok. Currently there are 3 monsters to play as. They all work differrent and can take some time to figure out, but I like it that way. Every game you have to adapt your play style to the map and monster. Each map has keys and other items scattered around. They spawn in different rooms each time so people can't memorize where they are each game. Playing as a survivor is exactly the same for each character, you have a flash light, you can opne doors (which is way more challenging than you'd expect) and pick up items. Items do different things so be sure to memorize which do what. The gameplay always varies and no game feels quite the same. There are a few bugs, but that'll get fixed. All around the maps are fun and challenging, the gameplay is scary, fun and working. This game is much better with friends toshare your screams and laughs. I give this game a 7/10

reviewText:
This review is 9 months after my original one. To my surprise, little to nothing in this game is fixed, and in fact seems worse than before. 9 times out of 10, you can't just join a game. Instead, you'll crash and burn! Over and over again! The login system is still as useless as ever, and is just a waste of time. Useless DRM.

Like I mentioned in my last review, unbalanced monster mechanics, locked to 30fps. Although, they recently fixed the frame-drops and general terribleness so that's a plus. Still not worth the $15 price tag. Get it on sale or don't get it at all and save yourself the frusturation of restarting the game constantly (and I mean constantly).

This game being Early Access STILL does not let it get away with being near unplayable and broken. They've had almost a year to fix these issues, but instead of fix things they add more 'features' onto the game.

Side-Note: Even if you don't crash, your friends sure can! Which means you have to restart the entire lobby just to play, and sometimes the entire game. It's better to just restart your game after every round.

That's not to say this game doesn't have potential, it really does, but in its current form its awful. Steam really needs more quality control.

EDIT: As of right now, apparently boards only go away for some people. So some people can't finish the game but others can walk through them. Good job!

reviewText:
Damned can only played in multiplayer where one player has to play as a monster and the rest as survivors who are trying to escape to somewhere safe. I read a handful of reviews because I don't understand the fun part of this game.

The level design is not bad and the game has potential but the gameplay is horrible IMO.  I like the part where the monster can set up traps so he knows where the survivors are and the limited time interval to manifest as a physical being but the monsters" doesn't look scary at all to me :/ maybe due to the stiff animations. It would be great to upgrade them with better animations which include  custom usable scare animations only to scare the hell out of the players :)

The objectives for the survivors could be more dynamic. At least where I played last time it was mostly to find keys so you can open doors which leads to the next area and this will be at the long run tiresome and boring for the survivors.

Another note that I almost forget to mention is that you need to create another account ingame to be able to play the game :P

All in all I think it is the best to watch some gameplay footage first before buying this game and I recommend to play this game with your friends for a better experience."

reviewText:
The first question I ask of you is: do you have friends? If no, then stop right here. You don't need to read anymore. If yes, then the next question is: do you value their friendship? If no, then doh, you rebel, you. If yes, then my very last question is this: do you want to keep them?

This game is absolutely terrifying and clearly, is best played with strangers.

No, no. I kid... definitely play this game with your friends. Strangers might end up scaring you more. Beg for their mercy if they're playing as one of the four monsters. Beg them to spare you and leave you alone - take the other person instead!". This is all you can do in Damned. Loyalties will be tested and friendships strained. Expect a few harsh words to come your way from someone whom you once cherised.

reviewText: Damned, quite literally, is what you get when you take the concept of Evolve and make it pure Survival Horror. Everything is randomized, so no two games will be the same. The atmosphere of the game alone is enough to get your heart pounding (Assuming you have your gamma setting where it should be), and the Monsters available at the moment are scary. When I say Scary, I mean it. One Jump scares, another paces around 'blindly', and the other Stalks you with traps. Not only is this game scary, but it is a blast to play with friends (So much Trolling and purposeful scares without wanting to kill them yet). To think that this game is in Beta, it makes me anticipate what more they could add to such an already great game. Personally, I love it, and I recommend it to everyone. Just be warned when I say this is a great Horror game. If you do not like horror, don't get it. The biggest downside i see is that it is online only, but that is the premise of the game.

reviewText:
After all this time it's still unplayable for me. This game is horribly optimized and full of bugs. I tried every fix available and still the game is running very badly.

It is such a fun concept and I would have probably loved it... If it actually was playable.
The best I got was 3 minutes in-game, 5 FPS, 300 ping, glitching characters and then a random crash.
I've got a good machine here, so it's not that.

I hope they'll fix these issues, otherwise this was just a big waste of money.
If they do, I'll update this review. But by the looks of it... it's not going to happen.

reviewText:
Game doesn't tell you what you can do, how you can do it and the framerate is god-awful (locked at 15fps for some reason on a GeForce 660 and Quad core AMD).

The game should lock down monster type to level, because some are blatantly overpowered for it.

It doesn't tell you that you can open doors, and that you need to hold the left mouse button to drag and open the door.

It doesn't tell you that you need to look at pumpkins to recharge, as a monster.

The NAT traversal doesn't happen, and when a game is up and running, there can be an issue where your framerate drops to 1fps and freezes, unless the host quits.

It's just buggy, I want to like it, the ghost mechanics kinda work but the people mechanics do not work, sprinting is a 'burst' type of thing and the controls are confusing and do not apply to every monster and it isn't clear what traits each monster has (place traps? teleport?).

Needs serious repair and rebuild.

reviewText:
Fun with friends but the amount of bugs and glitches makes this a horrible mess of a game that only shines in a few moments.

The premise is easy, you are dropped in a small map and you are either a survivor" or a "monster" with the choice between three different monsters each with their own powers and personalities.

However before this can be done you have to register??? for python some reason even though this game plays through steam. Sometimes this results in a crash and makes your game freeze and you have to use taskmanager to close it. restart... Now you probably want to fiddle with the graphical options as the game look and runs terrible. turning down the visual options helps getting the FPS from 8 to 25 easily...this game looks like it was made in unity like all the easy-to-make-horror-games of the last few years. However changing the graphical options makes the game hate you and freezes again
date: open task manager and close the game again.\n\nNow we get to join a room and this is where the fun begins. Because it's ALWAYS a gamble if you wil connect correctly. Sometimes the game joins a room but places you in a kind of limbo that shows no other players and doesn't allow you to start a game in any way
recommended: shape or form. the other kind is where it freezes upon start
hoursPlayed:
open task manager bla bla bla...

This game has a good concept and is really fun when it works however before you even get it to work you're already half an hour further and that is just not acceptable nowaday. If you want a good time with friends buy it on sale as a four-pack to have some laughs if you have the patience to get it all working.

"

reviewText:
Dont buy this game until the devs fix these massive netcode issues.

So this game WAS great, and now its unstable.
It was a great idea, and still is.
It used to be relatively stable, and now is toally error prone.
It was a great time with friends and randoms, but now is frustrating

And then the Menu-Game came.  Of the past 5 hours since re-installing this game last week, I've played maybe 3 matches. Much earlier in the lifecycle of this game, the game was relatively stable and showed great promise. Today my 4 friends and I spent 2 hours trying to login, trying to make a game, trying to join a game, and attempting to force close the game because it crashed hard.

In the end, it was better and the idea shows promise, but as of this review it is not worth the money until they fix these horrible stability issues. Don't buy this game until you start seeing positive reviews rolling through.

reviewText:
This game's features actively work against itself.

It's trying to be a horror game, but it's obtuse method of hiding the keys actively works to thwart any attempt at generating horror.  What it becomes is an exercise in Schadenfreude as one friend gleefully kills the rest while no progress is made.

The Haunts" are nothing more than tedious time-wasters that give an advantage to the already advantaged monster player.

End of the day

recommended: and barely manages to be a game.\n\nDo not buy."
