reviewText:
TL;DR: So bad, not worth.

Aside from the constant crashing at the start and insane lag even when running on a computer well beyond this game's requirements, there is pretty much no content. You spend ages in an almost atmospherically devoid environment looking for keys and various other crap without a clear objective aside from 'escape (insert random room here).'

Then comes the random ♥♥♥ ambience. You hear random things like what sounds like a hotel clerk bell and little bits of laughter for no reason.
With these immersion-disrupting sound bits tearing through your skull and the random screen darknening which is also jarring, you are very aware that you are playing a game. There is no mistaking it, the immersion leaves a lot to be desired.
Also, the enemies aren't particularly scary. If you see an enemy, you die silently. I tend to just run straight into the enemies because I feel 0 fear at all after the ambience has disrupted everything. The enemies are creepy-ish in their models alone because they arent particularly well done and it leaves a dirty-ish gross effect. Aside from that the game has pretty much nothing going for it.
Cool concept, poorly executed design, no immersion, not worth the 5 dollar sale.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Is this game still in alpha? Don't get me wrong, Damned is an amazing game; the 10% of the time you can actually play it. But in it's current state it's simply unplayable.

- The game crashes much more often than it doesn't. When you start a match it's VERY common for at least 2-3 of the 5 players to drop out because their game crashed. Judging by the fact the game is using 1,000,000k+ memory when I kill it, there's a memory leak somewhere.

- Upon rebooting the game, there's a myriad of random glitches. The most notable is the broken login screen. Others include sound simply not working, and lobbies not forwarding you into matches.

Outside of these glitches, there's a missing element to this game that's required for horror. There's almost no sound effects. Lurker lurches up to you and ravages you with his giant claws? COMPLETELY SILENT. There's spookity music playing, but you die without a sound. This is a huge problem with Mary, a little girl monster. If she stands near a survivor long enough she goes into a frenzy, and can completely wipe the whole party in seconds. You'd expect for there to be some sort of audio cue when she's nearby, you know to scare you, but nope. There's supposed to be a sobbing noise, but it's so faint(even with that audio maxed) that you can't realistically hear it.

The last problem I have with this game is that fact that monsters can cheese really hard if they know the map. Last night I witnessed a match where there was 1 survivor left, who had all the items he needed to escape out the final door. The enemy monster, the Phantom, was simply floating in front of the escape, slashing the air in front of the door. There was nothing the survivor could do. He had to open that door to win, and if he tried he would get killed.

The game has great potential, but until they fix their codebase you'll be fighting with the game's menus and glitches a lot more than playing the game.

reviewText:
A friend bought me this game and I still feel ripped off, god forbid you pay the full $19.99 for this game.

In short, this game is incredibly shallow and is obviously just a cash grab to get money from youtube lets players.

In long:

The gameplay doesnt even need to be boiled down to explain it, all you do is wander around a map trying its hardest to be scary (which is ruined immediately by the jack-o-lanterns) and pick up items, then you use these items to progress in the map and ultimately try to escape, the monster's job is to simply kill all the players.

This sounds great, except the entirety of the gameplay hinges around a single player, the monster. If the monster is playing to win, then the monster will win. EVERY. TIME. The monster has to 'play along' and try to actually scare the players, otherwise people will just drop dead and not understand why, as nothing is particularly clear and monsters will instantly kill you often before you even see them.

The maps have confusing layouts with no real logic tying them together with items strewn about in a random fashion, there are so many locked doors and rusty keys that it gets confusing very quickly.

The monster design is pretty horrible as well.

Mary just waits on a charge bar (that charges faster if the survivors look at you) then goes into frenzy and can instantly kill a player in a dash.

The Phantom can't see players unless they make sounds, except literally everything bar standing still makes sound, so basically it becomes a game of 'stand still and stare at the monster to survive', which can be easily abused and makes for a pretty idiotic mechanic

The Lurker is probably the only decently designed monster, as they place 'sound traps' where if a survivor trips it, both the survivor and the lurker knows it, the lurker then spawns in the area and looks for the survivor. However the lurker is on a 15 second timer giving survivors a chance to actually survive.

Finally, the game is buggy and fairly unfinished, with crashes around every corner, mysterious performance drops with no relation to hardware, horrible netcode, and connection issues.

Basically? DON'T BUY THIS GAME, IT ISNT EVEN WORTH 20 CENTS LET ALONE 20 DOLLARS.

reviewText:
Uh
Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The general idea and concept behind this game is great, Basically the game is similar to amnesia but with friends, and as we all know anything with friends is better even if the gameplay is dreaded.

In this case the gameplay is actually pretty good, Jump scares tend to be common and if u really jack the music up hairs will rase.

Playing as the monster is difficult but easy to pick up once you get going and alot of laughs can be had, playing as a human on the other hand can be scary to say the least, with a first person camera style and rather hard to see without your flash light on making this game one of those games where the more friends you have working together generally makes you wonder if its better to split up or stay together.

The main part that lets this game down significantly (at the moment atleast) is the fact that the game crashes constantly when entering or leaving a match, making actually getting into the game rather frustating to say the least not only that but the game isnt too well optimised at the momnet and even with everything turned down the game can at times run pretty badly.

If you have a group of friends this game is worth looking at if your up for a night of scares and fun, otherwise for now you can give it a miss

Overall Damned is a fun but scary game but in its current ALPHA state this game could be given a miss for a while id only recommend this game if you have friends willing to play with you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A rather interesting concept that we don't often see. Works well with 5 friends, not so much with random people. Unless said random people all leave their mics open or join a teamspeak server and share in good laughs when they get freaked out by a monster appearing in front of them or tearing them to pieces.

Ultimately though, this game is lacking variety right now. It is an Alpha, so I will give it that. The gameplay is simple, find the keys or codes to unlock doors or safes to find more keys and codes. Eventually, you'll find a tool to pull wooden boards off of a door. After that door is unlocked you escape from the monster. There are a few maps so far, so it does get repetitive eventually. Withut any dynamic events happening, I don't think it will ever stop being repetitive. Anyways, there are only two monsters aka creatures. One of which is not as fun as the other.

There's the Phantom. Which is the not-so-fun monster. As the Phantom you float around as a half decayed torso imbued with some evil magic or something. You float around decently fast and are allowed to pass through closed doors. Which is the only thing scary about this monster. From only a few play attempts it was clear to me that it was pretty overpowered and did not provide that great of an experience, both for the monster player, nor the character players.

The second and so far final monster, the Lurker is a rather intimidating piece of work. Though when I think about it, I find that it also resembles the Phantom in a way as they share a common trait. They both can get through closed doors. The Lurker is a little more difficult to get through though. There are two phases to this monster. Your ghost" phase
date: and your "flesh" phase. In the ghost phase you are unable to see or hear the players
recommended: but you're allowed to set traps. The traps range from pianos
hoursPlayed: to kitchen timers

reviewText:
This game is alot of fun and can be scary or funny as hell when played with some of your friends in co-op!

1 Player is the monster (there are currently 3 different monsters with different abilities) and the other 4 players are the survivors trying to escape. They have to find keys and codes to unlock doors and safes in a very dark and creepy enviroment like an Asylum or a Hotel!

It can be a BLAST when played with some people over voicechat and even the monster can communicate with or without a  voice changer (ingame) to creep the survivors out!

Sure the game has some bugs and crashes from time to time... but overall its an awesome coop horror experience!
If you like Amnesia and other similar games ... PICK THIS ONE UP !! ^^

reviewText:
Once you know what strategies to follow for each monster, the game becomes far less scary but even after 40h of playing, i still get fun and even tense sometimes, thanks for the community who tries their best to dub the monsters with passion, and even talent sometimes.

Phantom used to be a absolute threat before, and now, i find myself winning against him around half the time. Globally, the mechanics behind the three monsters are well tought, and i really love Mary.

I may reproach the lack of real diversity in the maps, but the main scratching part of this excelent game is the server stability, as many games may begin or finish by a crash or deconnexion.

Still, i would recommand this game, just for the pleasure of being haunted by a sad Mary, singing in german some lullabies.

reviewText:
As a giant wuss when it comes to Horror games, I was surprised to find that I wasn't too scared at first. We started by played 4 rounds cycling control of the monster (Mary was our first choice). Things weren't too bad, until the final round. My friend stumbled into Mary as I was running away up the stairs (having noticed her), and Mary frenzied up after me (without me realising). As I turned around to get my bearings, I finally noticed that Mary was after me - as my friend controlling her charged to within an INCH of me and then suddenly teleported, leaving me completely petrified looking down at the floor for the next 5 seconds, thinking I'd been killed. Needless to say, I spent the rest of the round in a complete panic and didn't last very long, and I'm not sure I can play against Mary any more :P

The only monster we have left to play is the Lurker. The phantom wasn't particularly terrifying, certainly not on the same level as Mary. If you want brown trouser moments, play against Mary.

Great fun with friends, especially if you're all sadistic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros
- good and fitting music
- pretty balanced gameplay
- randomly placed props and items
- quite stable during gameplay (except if and when a bug during a game causes bad frame rate lag)
- both the monsters AND the survivors are fun to play as
- extremely fun to play with friends

Cons
- extremely dull to play without friends
- playing as a survivor is harder since it requires good memorizing of the maps
- if you join a game that has already started, you'll have to wait untill next round
- can be very unstable, mostly in main menu, lobbies and when starting/joining a game (freezes, the cursor won't function when trying to click anything)
- rough around the edges" the controls may feel pretty clunky
- the asking price (20€)


I don't recommend buying this game IF...
- you have no friend to play it with

reviewText:
Be aware that Damned is it in its early stages but still delivers highly IMO for being what it is with such a small dev team.

I may have played it for about 3 hours, and is still quite the newbie by the time writing this review but those 3 hours have been GREAT, I'm not a huge fan of horror games & movies in general but this horror multiplayer is highly amusing even when you are sh'tting yourself or especially when you are even.

It will give you ALOT of jumpscares and mainly scary moments, whether you're playing alone or with your friends, this game is 4/5. (Although I would recommend having the option to play with friends to maximize the fun) Despite still being in the alpha phase and in early development and having some bugs and errors is the early access well worth it being what it is, a excellent horror multiplayer.

This game will haunt your human fears and bring you back for more and more even if it sometimes can possibly get repetitive when you are at that point when you know ALL the maps and monsters, but still the devs will most likely add more monsters and more maps and even possibly modding options over time to make it less repetitive and even more fun. If it wasn't for the minor bugs and (not so common) freezes/crashes and server crashes that need to be solved, I would have given it a 5/5 no doubt! But for being in alpha and being visually pleasing and auditory horrifying it is more than worth a buy especially when on sale as when I bought it! Buy if you have the money simply I consider it worth it!

+ Scary as in you will scream a lot of the time.
+ Fun as in it is a fun game to play simply.
+ Great range of maps.
+ Great monsters.
+ Great atmosphere
+ Visually pleasing and great sound design.
+ Hosting private and public games.
+ It's (really) hard to win as a survivor and I enjoy that.
+ Mary. End of story.

- BUGS etc.
- Missing some HUD options that would have been useful. (Light battery indicator etc.)
- IMO quite few monsters but as I said will most likely be added new ones with time
- Could be fun to add more survivors and monsters in a game such as a game mode with 2v6/8 instead of 1v4 in a near future.
- registering/login through their own servers and game. (Yet +" for the devs
date:
by highly decreasing piracy etc.)
- Door mechanic when opening/closing can be quite frustrating.
- Very small keys and batteries so you have to quite careful when searching.
- Nothing more I would add as a minus at this point really...

4/5!

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that I really love this game, or rather the potential this game has. In its current state I feel it falls short of what it could be.  I first bought this game roughly a year ago, and I'm disappointed with the amount of work that has gone into it since then.  This game doesn't need *more* content, it needs *refinement* of the existing content. I sincerely hope the developers will consider making some of the following adjustments:

Criticisms:
1) Communication.  Typically, most players choose to have their character randomly assigned.  The unfortunate side effect is that you don't know who YOU are playing as (assuming you're a human). Trying to tell your fellow survivors where items are becomes very difficult when they cant match your voice to your character.  Simply adding a portrait of your character on screen somewhere would help greatly.

2) Prolonged stalemates.  Most of the games I have played follow the same pattern, monster gets an early kill, eventually kills off a couple more, and then 3 players are stuck watching a stale mate of 1 monster vs 1 human for 20 minutes.  To exacerbate the problem, the dead players can't communicate with the living, which leaves both parties wondering if they should just give up for the sake of starting a new game.   I feel like some kind of mechanic needs to be implemented to bring the game to an end when it gets stalled in this way.  At the very least, players need to communicate how long they are willing to wait before abandoning the game.

3) Limited flash light usage.  When I first read about this in patch notes, it sounded exciting and a way to make the game more suspenseful.  In reality, it seems to bring the game to a grinding halt for all parties.  As a human, when your battery dies you cease making progress, and end up walking in circles aimlessly.  As the monster, your prey becomes harder to find, and the game reaches another stalemate.

4) Anti-climactic endings.  Regardless of which side wins, the game often ends with a yawn.  If a monster sneaks up and kills you from behind, you just fall over dead with out much idea of what happened to you.  If the survivors win, you just abruptly get notified that the game is over and are sent back to the lobby.  It would be nice if player deaths had a little more animation or violence added (it is a horror game after all), or if the survivors attempting to open the last door triggered some kind of global warning that would give the monster a brief moment of opportunity to get to the exit and stop them.

I really hope the developers will address these issues, as I've been a huge advocate of this game to many of my friends and coworkers.

reviewText:
Well, this game is pretty good for what i payed for. game play is amazing, because i definitely want to see a creepy girl behind me when the lights are off. If you are looking for a Co-op survival-horror game with decent graphics. cheap price for what you want, and countless hours of game-play? then this is for you.
A run-down of the game : three monsters to choose from. about eight maps to play. When making a server, just hit host and boom. No port-forwarding, and no more wasting 20 minuets trying to download a program that automatically port-forwards. Great game-play physics. A monster can set sound traps, and appear right in front of you, which is great for scary gaming moments, great with the lights off.
The only downsides to this game are the kicking system, the host can kick you instantly. (Which is fare, but i don't like it, i think it should require a vote.) And the optimization. Game-play can sometime be laggy. Which is fine, you should get at least 60fps if you have a decent video card, processor, and RAM. you can also see the specification recommendations on Damed's store page.
Thanks for reading, overall, 9.4/10

reviewText:
Do you like horror puzzle games without weapons like Amnesia, Penumbra, or Outlast?
Do you like co-op games like Left 4 Dead, or Payday?
Then this great but limited game of cat and mouse might be for you.

Playing as one of 4 survivors working together (or against each other) is terrifying especially when players start dropping like flies. Playing as one of 3 selectable monsters is extremely fun if you've read the guides to learn how they work because each one has different strengths/weaknesses and the game doesn't tell you anything.

Downsides:
Limited monsters to select
Very small amount of players on at any given time
Poor server browser with no ability to filter full or private matches (and no single player)
Prone to crashes and players drop out of matches too often, causing everyone else to leave.
Some graphical imperfections that take away from the experience

Still love it, and would like to see the game progress in future.

reviewText:
Worth it on a Steam sale when all your friends buy it and play together.

HOWEVER I have a very important issue with this game that other people have as well. The Insanity System is literally one of the most annoying and disappointing things I have ever seen for a game. I hate horror games, movies etc, but I love it when the scares derive from the PLAYERS in the game, like in this one! But just less than an hour ago the Insanity System has caused me to stop playing due to fear.

I didn't even know this feature was in the game until earlier when I was hiding from a friend playing as Mary (who is TERRIFYING) and a CREEPY AS ♥♥♥♥ FACE FLASHED ONTO MY SCREEN and I think I pooped myself. Yes I get scared a bit easily but again, this had the potential to make me enjoy a horror game which I usually don't like as a genre. I play Depth, a game with sharks and the ocean, when I am terrified of BOTH, and I love it, because the scares are natural, balanced and fair.

The Insanity System saps all fun from the experience as the scares are no longer being produced from a balanced, real system. When someone is playing as the monster and you get scared, it's OK because you know they were simply using the game's features, which you understand and have the ability to counteract based on your knowledge of the monster.

Now it's not ALL bad. Some of the features include strange noises/music playing, the lights flickering, and even your keyboard keys losing response. Despite the keys thingy, I think those ideas are alright as long as they create TENSION and not FEAR. The one feature of the Insanity System that RUINS the experience are the face jumpscares (I think it's the people who have died flash onto your screen?) that occur when you have been alive and hiding for a while.

When a face flashes onto your screen, you have absolutely NO idea when, where or why it appears and it's not even controlled by the player as the monster. It's an unfair system that ruins the balance. The monster and humans have an equal environment to win. A face flashing onto your screen is random and unfair.

Overall a very fun game but the Insanity System is making me fear playing it again in case it shows up again. If there was an option to remove it, I would love this a lot more. Would love if the faces got removed or turned into an option, considering how the devs have been aware of the dislike for this feature for about seven to eight months.

reviewText: I had a blast playing this game for the first time last night.  Was playing with several friends, and we were taking turns playing the monster.  I had a ton of fun tormenting my friends as Mary, a monster that is basically the little girl from The Ring.  I would see their flashlights shining around, and I would just try to stand somewhere just out of sight, so they'd turn the corner and see me standing there motionless, and then yell and run.  Once, a new friend joined the game, and he saw me standing still, and wasn't sure if I was the monster or what.  He just kept his light on me and was asking in voicechat if the girl was a monster or a friendly.  Then I suddenly went into frenzy mode and rushed directly at him.  The resulting shrieks of terror had me laughing my ♥♥♥ off.  The game was a lot of fun, and we'll definitely be playing some more.

reviewText:
Very spooky and fun to play with your friends.

But there's a lot of bugs, the game sometimes crashes after the loading screen without a message, and in some places you can't for example walk between two tables, even though there is plenty of space. You may also not be able ot walk over the slighest obstacle, an Ouija board for example.

Theres also no level editor, which makes me sad.

Doors, drawers and lockers can be very difficult to open, as the game has a very severe case of mouse acceleration, along with a bit clunky controls.

It can be EXTREMELY hard for the survivors to complete a match, since some of the maps are very VERY linear, and with keys being difficult to find at most time. The phantom monster is very OP, since you only have to camp at a door in one the linear maps to win the entire game in just a few seconds. I highly suggest you play with life mode and set max deaths to 6.

The game has a real neat 3D voice feature, which means the host can change it so that you can only hear people speak if they were close to you. This can be frustrating though if you're playing a large map with many ways to go.

Totally not worth 20 euro in it's current state, but if its on sale and you get it for 3,99 as I did, you should totally get it.

I rate this game 6/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very suspenseful and exciting. When played at night with friends, Damned is incredibly entertaining. The immersion is accentuated by 3D directional voice communication, which is honestly one of my favorite features for a game to have.

Visually, the game isn't ridiculously impressive; although, its graphics and effects do fine at achieving the game's spooky atmosphere.

My only qualm is with the volumetric fog. It looks great but it brings the performance down by a factor of ten on my system. I've played plenty of games with the same feature, and I hardly lost any framerate. Hopefully the developers find some way to better optimize the fog for performance.

Overall: Great game, very spooky 8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The general idea and concept behind this game is great, Basically the game is similar to amnesia but with friends, and as we all know anything with friends is better even if the gameplay is dreaded.

In this case the gameplay is actually pretty good, Jump scares tend to be common and if u really jack the music up hairs will rase.

Playing as the monster is difficult but easy to pick up once you get going and alot of laughs can be had, playing as a human on the other hand can be scary to say the least, with a first person camera style and rather hard to see without your flash light on making this game one of those games where the more friends you have working together generally makes you wonder if its better to split up or stay together.

The main part that lets this game down significantly (at the moment atleast) is the fact that the game crashes constantly when entering or leaving a match, making actually getting into the game rather frustating to say the least not only that but the game isnt too well optimised at the momnet and even with everything turned down the game can at times run pretty badly.

If you have a group of friends this game is worth looking at if your up for a night of scares and fun, otherwise for now you can give it a miss

Overall Damned is a fun but scary game but in its current ALPHA state this game could be given a miss for a while id only recommend this game if you have friends willing to play with you.

Very suspenseful and exciting. When played at night with friends, Damned is incredibly entertaining. The immersion is accentuated by 3D directional voice communication, which is honestly one of my favorite features for a game to have.

Visually, the game isn't ridiculously impressive; although, its graphics and effects do fine at achieving the game's spooky atmosphere.

My only qualm is with the volumetric fog. It looks great but it brings the performance down by a factor of ten on my system. I've played plenty of games with the same feature, and I hardly lost any framerate. Hopefully the developers find some way to better optimize the fog for performance.

Overall: Great game, very spooky 8.5/10

reviewText:
While I enjoy this game quite a bit, I wouldn't recommend it to others, at least at the point of me writing this.

There are quite a few bugs that occur frequently, such as a key glitching out of a map, causing an unwinnable situation for the survivors. Another problem that frequently occurs (for me, at least) is that when I, or one of my friends, kill someone as a monster, there is a dead body on the ground, but a new body spawns in. Granted, the survivor is still dead, but this causes an unfair advantage for a monster like Mary, who can just sit beside this new body and build energy. Also, while this could be attributed to bad ping or something like that, I find that the hit detection in the game can be absolute trash. Either as the monster, swinging at a survivor, my hand going through them, but them still living, or as a survivor, when I spend a good minute trying to open a door or drawer, and then the next time I attempt it, I do it without effort. One last problem would be the insanity. While it sounds like a good idea on paper, it becomes very annoying, very fast. At first, it adds an extra sense of unease, which is good for a horror game, but there's a fiar amount of randomness that comes with it. Eventually, it can get to the point where your entire screen goes dark, mixed with being slowed down, to the point that it's just unfair.

If you insist on getting this game as it is now, I definitely suggest you play with insanity turned off, and with some friends  to liven up the game even a little bit.

If the developers ever end up fixing all of the problems, then this game would definitely be one that I recommend.

reviewText: If you're interested in Damned, then you have to be ready to put up with a handful of things including, but not limited to, that one missing key, the fact that the game doesn't always 100% work for everyone consistently due to bugs or other nonsense, and last, but not least, the fact that mary is scary. This game is an exciting horror escape game that feels kind of like a point and click game given a first person engine, only because you're running around to specific rooms and running through them to grab at keys to open new rooms etc. Knowledge is probably the most valuable weapon in this game because an inexperienced player is almost always going to lose, but that's all part of the horror fun as the monster gets to toy with them a little bit beforehand. All in all the game has its unique charm, but you will most likely have to have a group of 5 friends to really enjoy the game to its fullest.

Played with a full group of friends. Everyone, including the monster - on Skype. We figured we can't really tell each other where we were because of that, so I came up with the brilliant idea of using turning on and off my flashlight to indicate to the others. We proceed to find a bunch of keys and stuff - so far so good.
5 minutes later one of my buddies is dead and another one has splitted off the group so it's just the two of us searching the level. Shortly we find the key to the exit, my heart is racing, all excited and stuff when the one who went to search alone starts shouting on Skype that the monster is chasing him. We two decide to let him die, since he is distracting the monster anyway and we can escape meanwhile. I run to the other side of the room, open the door and see the 'being-chased' running past me, monster following. Well, not exactly. I died in a split second and the other two followed shortly.

Pants were ♥♥♥♥. Will play again.
10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BRIEF SYNOPSIS: You can have great jump scares with this beta 3D multiplayer horror adventure where you play either one of four survivors trying to escape, or a horrifying monster attempting to kill the survivors; recommended despite bugs (see forums). * Spoilers below *

GAMEPLAY REVIEW:
Summary:
My childhood nightmares come to life. I'm a wimp when it comes to anything horror, but the multiplayer adventurer in me as drawn me in. It is brilliant to have four different human survivors as a team versus one human-controlled monster. And the three current monsters are terrifying, along with the ten existing levels full of creepy ambiance and atmosphere.

Escape is difficult but not impossible for the survivors, who need to find keys and codes to unlock and open doors and safes, use batteries to power their flashlights, grab a crowbar or hammer to smash wooden boards, and eventually escape the monster or fall victim to it. The longer it takes to complete a level, the more the survivors become insane and the more difficult it becomes to escape.

In game chat:
I really enjoyed using the 3d audio with a microphone headset. It makes a huge difference in the game. Everyone can hear you speaking, so if you want to keep the monster guessing use the in-game text chat (brought up with the enter key). It's also good with chatting in-between rounds in the lobby.

Game play seems to favour the monsters, but smart survivors will be able to team up to outwit their pursuer to escape. Even in death, survivors can text chat with the living to give helpful hints, such as “You missed a key in the sink,” or “I have a crowbar with my body on the main floor.”

Lobby:
After logging in you can setup your options and either join or host your own game. Hosts can have an open game lobby or set a password to have a private game amongst friends only. Some people have complained about being kicked out of games but I think most people who want private games have figured out how to the use password now. Those of you still kicking people, stop being so lazy and use a password for your private games (May the Lurker devour your soul...). The people hosting and the people I've played with in this community have been courteous and fun to play with. Thanks people for making this game even more fun! Most people seem to be on the servers during the weekends.

Life mode seems better if you are casually hosting players – people can join in whenever they feel like if there is a spot. Normal mode is more hard core with only one life to live or die with.

Levels:
There are currently ten levels consisting of three hotels, three asylums, a hospital (asylum set), a restaurant (hotel set), a warehouse (hotel set), and a factory. Each are different sizes and have different strategies. Some have two exits which help prevent monster camping at the exit. Some have stairs and different levels. Some have too many damn tables. Each level is creepy and atmospheric. I AM HOPING FOR GRAVEYARD TYPE LEVELS FOR A FUTURE UPDATE. There are only three different set types for levels (asylum, hotel, or factory).

Survivors:
There are four player controlled survivor models:
Mia the emo; she appears to be Asian and wears miss-matching shoes.
Scott the jockey, sporting his Eagles college jacket.
Jacob the nerd; he is of African descent and a little stout.
Father John the priest; he totes a Bible but it's not compelling monsters to go away.

The survivors typically start in a room and have to find keys and codes to unlock doors and safes that will eventually allow them to escape from the level. The survivors are equipped with a battery burning flashlight that needs to be replenished or they will be forced to grope around in the dark. The longer the survivors take to complete a level, the more insane they will become. Others tools survivors will need include either a crowbar or a small hammer to remove boards from exit or storage doors. [A shovel is needed in the graveyard level.] - oops, sorry, don't know how that got in there... There are no weapons or way to attack the monster, which makes then all the more scary. Repeat, there is no BFG to save you!

Monsters:
There are currently three monsters that one player can choose to hunt down the survivors. I feel the monsters are generally well-balanced. Some people feel the Phantom is still overpowered, despite all the tweaks it has been receiving as of late. Survivors must adjust their game-play for each monster in order to escape.

Mary is the scariest monster and my current favourite. She is a great monster with pretty blue eyes, but she has some posture issues. She seems well balanced with her movements and attacks. Her walk mode is a little slow, but her attack is long reaching and swift. Quick manoeuvring for survivors is the key when you hear her scream. Mary has some movement issues over objects and the Factory catwalk.

The Lurker is a muscular hulk with two forms. The first form is spiritual and allows the Lurker to freely roam the level, unencumbered by doors. In this mode it can set sound traps that go off when a survivor is nearby to help it locate the players as it cannot see anyone in this form. Once the Lurker is powered up by time it can enter its physical form where it can visibly stalk and kill remaining survivors. After a while the Lurker will revert to its spiritual form where it will have to wait until it recharges and takes physical form again. The longer the Lurker remains in physical form, the longer it take to recharge in spiritual form.

The Phantom is a roaming skeletal ghost (the creepiest monster for me until Mary joined) that can see survivors via sound such as the clicking of flashlights, running, or setting off a trap. Then it's either run away for the survivors and try to escape the Phantoms detection radius or get eviscerated by it. When the Phantom hears a survivor, it can see a white shadow, even through walls or different levels, of where the player is.

Traps are set automatically for the Phantom and Mary, whereas setting traps is part of the Lurker's strategy. They are generally objects strewn about the level. Each trap makes a different sound to alert a monster to where a survivor is.

Sound:
The music is great for a horror game. Each monster has its own terrifying theme music when it appears near a survivor. Ambient sounds like footsteps, breathing, traps, and screams add to the atmosphere. The 3D audio chat really adds to the game-play; it is great to taunt the survivors as a monster. Dead players can only text chat.

Insanity system:
The insanity system increases game difficulty by darkening a survivor's screen to the point of complete darkness, making the flashlight flicker on and off, causing the player to hear random sounds, losing hearing, losing colour vision, having arms emerge from the ground that slow or halt a survivor's progress, randomly disabling a directional key on your keyboard, and flashing images of possessed survivors across your screen. The effects are temporary but potentially deadly.

The insanity mode is a great idea and has been toned down from beta 1.0 to occur less frequently. It serves its purpose of making the game especially difficult the longer the survivors take to exit. Apparently the jump scare faces have been fixed so that they don't blind you, but I have yet to see the new effect since my game currently freezes before it occurs. I feel the jump scares are not necessary in this game. Also annoying for fair game-play is the keyboard/mouse movement disabling effect.

CONCLUSION:
Despite bugs being ironed out during the beta period, I feel the game is a very enjoyable if not a mildly terrifying experience. It's best played with all five people, and the up to four survivors really need to cooperate to escape from the monster. Recommended for beta and if all bugs (especially game freezing/crashing) get squashed for the retail release.

Edited 2014-08-26 - [Version Beta 1.12a]

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA simple but brilliant game. Although it is still in Alpha, it has an eerie atmosphere and keeps you on edge. The basic plot is to find your way out of the building using keys and codes. At the same time, you must be stealthy and aware of the monsters. This can make gameplay very fun and strategic, and certainly gives you chills. In my opinion playing with a headset on mic with your teammates is the best way to play this game. Despite its simplicity, it does take a lot of effort to finish the games. One particular monster is OP which makes gameplay mostly irritating but sometimes fun. There are a lot of annoying bugs, the most significant one being not being able to log in and having to restart over and over again until it works. Also, you get disconnected a lot and your whole computer will freeze.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I find this game really fun, especially in the first time in the areas, I was so unfamiliar and getting horribly frightened especially when the lurker set off item traps so everything started dinging and going off around me.

As fun as it is, I feel the level variety and maps could be a bit more mazelike, confusing to both the monster and the humans, making it harder to track as well as potential changes to monster styles. As stated in another players review, they recommended a way of allowing the Lurker to interact directly with objects to scare people, without actually being able to kill them. Beyond that, I find the Lurker insanely fun with setting traps and waiting for the careless humans to set off my traps to alert me to their location. I remember once I waited for the traps to alert me, and as soon as one right next to me went off, I turned physical, staring face to face mere feet away from 2 humans, who both panicked in their attempts to run away.

In addition, I feel that the Phantom should have its range reduced a bit and if possible, sound waves emanate from the area sound was made, whether from a trapped item, or from a persons steps, and make it easier to track a person through small bits of sound, but in areas where theres lots of sounds going on, it could become confusing to the phantom what sounds are actually people or are the items. Either that, or make it so the phantom has to actually attack like the lurker does to kill, and not just walk through the person.

Another suggestion I would have at the moment (not knowing if/what monsters will be added as well as maps) is to have specially designed large maps that can support up to 10 players, and 2 players play monsters. Imagine them working as a team, the Lurker setting traps and turning physical right in front of people, and in their panic, they run away, attracting the attention of the Phantom or continues the chase. I feel it would be a much more intense experience for people if it were balanced properly.

Overall, I feel the game has immense potential and am really excited to see the game grow.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nImagine the survival-horror and puzzle solving of Amnesia but there are 4 people trying to work together and survive in a multiplayer map.  The survivors must find their way out of the map (dungeon, asylum, etc) by finding keys to open doors, find crowbars to break open secret areas and much more.  Instead of various AI monsters you have to avoid there is a fifth player who plays as a single monster who works to kill you.  One monster can walk through doors while the other one can lay traps for the survivors.  There are a few more buffs and negs to the monsters such as movement speed and one monsters 'mortal form.'  The map is randomly generated at the start of the round so no two matches feel the same.  This game is very fun and intense.  At the time of writing this it is in alpha so it is buggy for now and needs a few balance tweaks.  There are two types of monsters that players can play as and each one has their pros and cons.  Buy the 4 pack and make that friend you don't care for to much pay for it himself and kill him or her over and over again.

reviewText:
I hate to give it a no because it has so much potential. Right now the game is excessively difficult to play and unbalanced in the favor of monsters. There are two types of characters, the survivors, who search for things such as batteries (to power your limited flashlights), tools (to help you open barricades) and keys (to help you open locked doors).

To open locked doors, you have to hold left click, then push or pull the door in the direction the door opens. This is cumbersome, and with all the other issues in the game, such as the extremely imprecise cursor, it is a feature of the game that really should have taken bakesat to fixing other things. Doors should just open and shut.

I am a 260 pound man and I think the survivor characters run like a bunch of chain smoking grannies with rusty walkers. I could outrun them after a night of no sleep. That's saying something.

Ultimately, the game has a lot of potential, but right now, the difficulty of finding the tools you need to escape, the anticlimactic escape situations, the absence of a story line and voice acting, the poor. In time the game might become playable.

reviewText:
This game is still early access, so this review is subject to change/additions

Damned is basically what it says on the Tin. A survival horror game for 5 players (Maximum) where four play scavenger hunt Point A to point D item findings, and one player plays one of (Currently 3) monsters to murder your friends. Fun for everyone, especially if you have friends who enjoy screaming very loudly at your music-cue arrival. Lets get down to it.

Gamplay involves item-based problem solving. Simple stuff. Find key, key goes to Locker, locker goes to safe, safe goes to kitchen, kitchen goes to crowbar, crowbar goes to wood over door, escape through door. Not always that simple, but basically always that formula. You have to find keys, unlock doors and safes, and escape out of the final door while eluding the monster player. Not always so easy.

The Monster player has 3 monsters to choose from (At the time of this review) being Lurker, Phantom, and Mary. Lurker is your tall and gruesome skinless hulkbeast who spends a majority of the game in Phase mode" which is where the player will move around quickly
date: phasing through doors (Cause you cant see them) and players (Who you also cant see) and setting traps. Since you can't see players
recommended: you need to use the traps to figure out their locations. Once they set one off
hoursPlayed: and it lets you phase in
voteText: you pop in and slice them to ribbons.\n\nThe phantom is like a satanic stevie wonder. A floating torso who is completely blind to anyone unless they make a lot of sound. This means running
helpfulPercent: and clicking your flashlight. And getting too close. Make too much noise
votesHelpful: and you'll show up in his vision as a white life-form that he can go maul. It's a fairly simple system
votesTotal: and I've nearly had it gotten around when I played him.\n\nMary is your near-typical japanese-horror esque girl. Similar in design to popular ones like the Ring
votesFunny: or grudge. For a majority of the game she moves slower than a 95 year old man walking through hot tar. She also randomly teleports as a way to balance and make your life easier. You might teleport in the same room as the players
commentsCount: might not. You can also manually teleport
column16: but we'll get to that in a second.\n\nMary has the ability to enter a /frenzy/ mode when her meter (Which you dont see) fills. Stare at the players enough
column17: and you can activate frenzy mode. a 10-15 second burst of quadrupled speed in which she screams violently
column18: goes all scary faced and comes bullrushing you. You can also exchange a bit of the frenzy meter for another teleport
column19: if you dont wanna wait for the freebie random one.\n\nThere are about 12+ stages right now
column20: with the most recent (At the time of this review) being a forest/camping area. The game does have some flaws
column21: like optimization issues
column23: and minor coding bugs. Updates are also somewhat slow
column24: but when they come around they are very nice. Running on my toaster I get about 25-30 frames in a map. Apparently a high-end gets about the same
column25: due to optimization issues. It happens.\n\nI can't really rate it with a number right now
column26: but I am giving it a yes. It's a nice game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is in its early beta state, so I'm gonna write a review based on that.

First of all, keeping in mind that it is an early beta, the game is simply amazing. The main idea of the game is very original, and I've had some heart attacks playing the game, yes, it does scare you ;). To think that the game is an early beta ( sorry for so much early beta early beta :p ) and it scares is something that makes me think that the game has potential, yet the game is buggy, since beta bla bla and the performance is rather poor. But that is something that can be fixed! :)

The maps are also nice, the only thing I don't really like about them are the exits, you reach one room and ta-da! you've won. You could die in that room also irl, I'd make something better like getting out of the building or whatever, with a little cutscene. BUT AGAIN! it's an early beta, what has to come will come.

In conlusion, the game is good, has potential to become an awesome game, and the main idea of the game already works.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very very fun.  And gameplay is simple yet very complex.

There are 4 humans trying to escape a building.  Throughout each map are keys and other items that the humans need to find in order to escape.  The placement of the items and paths randomize on each map so you have a different experience each time.  As a human you use a combination of left mouse button and mouse movements to open and close doors and drawers.  You also get a flashlight and you can sprint for short periods of time (with a slow regen of sprint).  You can't fight the monsters; all you can do is run, hide and die.

There are 2 types of monsters with very different abilities.  The basic mission for the monster is to kill all the humans which is often easier said than done.

This game is very fun to play as people will regularly freak out and scream sounding like a little girl.  GET IT NOW!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know I've only played 2 hours, but it's an alpha and currently there isn't much new past 2 hours.
This game is fun as hell.
Disclaimer: I play with a set group of friends who are guaranteed to communicated well & effectively, your experience with random public players will likely be less than satisfactory.

This game is really fun, especially when you know everybody. When you're being hunted by the monster you get frantic looking for keys, and when you're the monster it's amazing just trying to plan out when you're going to get survivors or if you just want to scare them for a little bit.

Since this is an alpha, there are a few glitches. Some people have issues with alt-tabbing, other times players apparently can't connect. There is also the occassional crash (I haven't crashed or experienced any bugs except the following one). The only game-breaking bug (as in you have to go to a new round) is when you spawn in a room and cannot get out or if you cannot continue, however this is extremely rare.

This game shows a lot of promise and is currently extremely fun. There is proximity chat which can be hilarious when the lurker uses it!

reviewText:
In Damned, four people play as survivors and one as a spooky monster. There are three monsters implemented so far to choose from, each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses. The survivors collect keys and batteries and try to open enough doors to get to the exit. A very simple premise to a game that can be loads of fun, but also equally annoying when you meet someone who just uses the monster to wipe everyone out in the first minute.

Damned is a game about chilling fear, amazing atmosphere and occasional jump scares. I think a lot of people underestimate the value of stalking a completely frightened prey, instead of killing it immediately. It’s priceless. I’ve seen things in this game that only happen in the best Horror movies, and have left me spooked to death.

Let’s be clear, it’s not perfect. There are still numerous bugs, sometimes the map or a character will get bugged and you won’t be able to progress. Is it still worth the money? For the full price, maybe (simply because it's buggy and laggy). For the 50% discount that happens pretty much every month, definitely.

reviewText:
Still needs some work but has a lot of potential. This game is very entertaining with friends especially when in a skype call  hearing them scream. xD

Gameplay is fun but can get tedious at times, especially with occasional choppy fps. I've also had a time where i was unable to find the key i needed to progress, looked literally everywhere but was forced to quit- a shame as it would have been the first time i completed a game succesfully. There is a sense of acheivement though especially when playing in smaller maps because keys work on specific doors- that was a good idea.

Graphics are impressive compared to other games i'm able to play on my low end computer- definately the best i've been able to play with on this pc. Level design is varied slightly so you aren't getting the same thing everytime but the good, dark, ominous atmoshpeare stays consistant throughout the game.

Connecting with friends is easy and quite stable. However, there used to be a bug which prevented the host starting the game. Another one was when i was invited to play and joined the server but the host did not appear to be there. I'm not sure if this has been fixed yet or not though.

Some things i'd love to see in the future is ai monsters, that would allow parties of two to both experience scares at the same time and work together. Pulling off ai that doesn't immediately just pop up and ruin the scare factor of the game would make me very impressed. Also a campaign would be great! giving the characters a background story to help us connect to them emotionally would definetly make an exciting experience. Great work from the developers so far, i cant wait to see what they bring in the full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Damned takes the best parts of TTT and mashes it together with Prophunt, Darkest Days, and The Hidden.

It's legitimately terrifying, and has randomly generated maps and objectives. A player is randomly selected to be the monster, and each monster requires a different playstyle both to hunt, and to dodge.

Objectives are random and strewn across the map, but scripted  in such a way that that requires you to cover the entire map to escape. You'll never spawn in a room you can't escape from.
voteText: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is proof that a game can have co-op/multiplayer and still be incredibly scary.

There's a good variety of maps in the game, and the developers seem to add more and more every once in a while. There's a lot of variety in the monsters. One person gets to be the monster while the others are humans trying to escape. The monster player can choose from a handful of monster types, including a blind ghost who can only see by sounds (like sprinting, opening/closing doors, etc.), a ghost girl that's basically Samara from The Ring, and a large brute creature that can turn invisible.

Sadly, the game seems to be dying. The last few nights that I've tried to play, I haven't been able to get into a single match. There's always a private server with 2 or 3 players in it (the game is 5 player max), and then one sole person sitting in a server, but no one else joins (and 1v1 isn't very exciting in this game).

It's a great game, and by far the best multiplayer horror game (White Noise Online is the only other one I can think of, though), but while I do recommend it, I only recommend buying it if it's on sale (meaning there'll be more people playing it while it's on sale) or if you have at least two or three other friends wanting to also play it with you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game,
The same fear levels & enjoyment as with Slender Man,
The only difference is, it's one of YOU who is the monster!...

The only thing wrong with this game I can see at the moment is the player pool!...
Where is everybody? This game has so much to offer, yet so little people are interested.

Maybe they should try giving a free for 24-48 hour opportunity.

The maps are lovely & spooky, the monster is really creepy looking, and theres more monsters to come!,
the music drives you slightly insane, and there is nothing worse than being on your own for too long.

I'm really looking forward to this new insanity system, I think it will really give players a chill while being the last survivor!

I hope to see more of you creeping down the halls!

Fully recommend this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very very fun.  And gameplay is simple yet very complex.

There are 4 humans trying to escape a building.  Throughout each map are keys and other items that the humans need to find in order to escape.  The placement of the items and paths randomize on each map so you have a different experience each time.  As a human you use a combination of left mouse button and mouse movements to open and close doors and drawers.  You also get a flashlight and you can sprint for short periods of time (with a slow regen of sprint).  You can't fight the monsters; all you can do is run, hide and die.

There are 2 types of monsters with very different abilities.  The basic mission for the monster is to kill all the humans which is often easier said than done.

This game is very fun to play as people will regularly freak out and scream sounding like a little girl.  GET IT NOW!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know I've only played 2 hours, but it's an alpha and currently there isn't much new past 2 hours.
This game is fun as hell.
Disclaimer: I play with a set group of friends who are guaranteed to communicated well & effectively, your experience with random public players will likely be less than satisfactory.

This game is really fun, especially when you know everybody. When you're being hunted by the monster you get frantic looking for keys, and when you're the monster it's amazing just trying to plan out when you're going to get survivors or if you just want to scare them for a little bit.

Since this is an alpha, there are a few glitches. Some people have issues with alt-tabbing, other times players apparently can't connect. There is also the occassional crash (I haven't crashed or experienced any bugs except the following one). The only game-breaking bug (as in you have to go to a new round) is when you spawn in a room and cannot get out or if you cannot continue, however this is extremely rare.

This game shows a lot of promise and is currently extremely fun. There is proximity chat which can be hilarious when the lurker uses it!

reviewText:
Outstanding Multiplayer Survival Game.
10/10 britches were soiled.

Money well spent.

reviewText: Damned is a survival horror game where Humans are trapped inside a map for example a asylum and have to escape. While theyre trying to find keys to escape theyre not alone, Theyre being hunted by monsters (Lurker, Phantom or Mary) All monsters have advantages and disadvantages. For example mary is a very slow moving character but when you stare at humans for a certain amount of time she will be given the option to go into frenzy mode meaning she will then be really fast and then will be able to kill the humans. The goal is to escape as humans or to kill evey human thats trap inside as a monster.\n\nThis game is alot of fun especially with groups of friends in a skype or steam group call which can make games insanly fun and alot of funny moments. I would give this game a 9/10 and definatly recomend it to anyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not as good as it could have been. Well, not at this moment. It's still in Alpha and I really regret buying it, even during a sale.
The engine is faulty, the level design boring and the flash light is of no use, because you can just walk around without any and still see plenty.
A tutorial is a far as abscent, which is a no go for any serious game.

Okay, it's alpha, but that doesn't mean that you're allowed to sell every bit of trash on Steam as a potential front runner.
Believe me, Damned is a bad game. Bad graphics, bad gameplay, bad sound effects and a really bad user interface design.

reviewText:
This is my first review but i hope this helps other people see how awesome this game is. I know I have only played this game for like 2 hours but thats all you need for such an awesome game however there were some parts that were annoying but wasnt enough to destroy the game play.

Outside of gameplay:
+ I experienced that the cursor was guite laggy (slight stutters)
+ If you did not put full screen on your cursor could not click the side options (so put fullscreen on)
+ Sometimes Alt+tab would glitch my resolution or just crash the game so I just avoided that.

Gameplay:
+ Fun to play (if you have friends)
+ The maps are good but if there is not time limit it can get a bit boring as some of the maps are big making it hard and iritating for anyone playing the monster.
+ The monsters are cool and its nice they have some handi caps so they are not too OP
+ I feel there should be more than 3 monsters but the game is still tons of fun just with 3 because they all have their own unique ability.
+ More monsters to choose from would be nice
+ If normal characters had special abilities assigned to them would be awesome.

Overall, this game is fun even for someone like me who hates these kind of games but its just a great way fro you and your friends to engage with each other, if you like thrillers/jumpscares.

reviewText:
Unifinished and frustrating.

Once you're in the game: it's amazing. As a survivor, you're scrambling, looking for the keys out of the haunted area while freaking yourself out as every sound and odd sight could be sign of the monster coming to kill you in one hit.

As a monster, it's an incredibly fun game of hide and seek, where you're trying to get in the head of survivors and figure out where they're gonna be, Monsters are slow, so kills are almost always accomplished by laying out an ambush.

The problem is it crashes and bugs out so often, usually leaving you hanging on a screen with no notion of what's happening. I figure about 25% of my time playing this game is spent dealing with crashes, bugs, and looking for viable online games to join. This game should still be listed as Early Access, caveat emptor.

reviewText:
If you're the kind of person who gets frustrated by bugs preventing you from playing 50% of the time, please wait until you try Damned. Otherwise you'll get to enjoy 10-15 minutes at a time of a fun, engaging experience trying to outrun a creepy monster that makes you afraid of even using your flashlight.
Except, then you die, you try to find another lobby to keep playing..... aaaaaand you crash/freeze.

In all of 1 hour's play, my personal experience was:
- Multiple Server down for maintenance" messages preventing connection.
- Multiple "Your account is already in use" messages when trying to reconnect after a crash.
- Connected to lobbies without seeing anyone when the player count is above zero.
- Connection causes a crash.
- Game load causes a freeze. Arriving in a game right after load = also a freeze.
- Graphics flickers on older (3 year-old) systems
date:
really affects the experience negatively (I was on a LAN with a friend whose computer is not powerful enough to play this simple game well).


Get past the above and the game is fun
hoursPlayed: it's always a gamble as to whether you'll be able to reconnect without a crash or a freeze and play for longer than one session.\n\nI'll edit this if and when they fix the bugs... until then
voteText: will not be touching it again."

reviewText: Can't recommend it at this point in time. It's got some real entertaining moments, but there are too many little things that ruin it. The game is heavily biased in favor of the monsters. It's very rare for the survivors to actually win the round. The maps are garbage and cluttered with too much stuff that gets in the way. And the biggest issue is that when people leave the game, which they do frequently, the character they were playing as goes away, but late joiners can't replace them. So usually the game quickly turns into a 1v2 instead 1v5. Maybe they'll improve it in the future. Like I said, it's fun. Anyone who wants a quick fix survival horror game will enjoy it for a while, but it's got too many problems to last.

reviewText:
Do NOT buy this game.

Go look at the forums please. I got this game on sale a while back and it was a big mistake.
The idea of the game is fun, but the idea has been done much better on other games.

This game rarely gets updates. The community on the game is not high. The monster selection is low and the surviver selection is low. If you play one to two matches with each monster then you will get the game. When the monster you would think it is fun, but no it isn't. As the monster you spend most of the time running around hoping to bump into someone. As a survivor you run around hoping to find a key. You will only get a fast, maybe interesting, game if both monster and players know the map by heart and memory and where stuff tends to be located. Sometimes the game will bug and you can't pick up a key you need or open a door even if you have the right key. Also, if you are playing and the person as the monster leaves the game your entire game is ruined and you are ♥♥♥♥ed. The game wont end automatically nor will it put someone as the monster like any good game mechanic would do.

The game itself is really buggy. The engine this runs on is apparently poop so thats a thing.

Here is their official website:
http://www.9heads.com/games/damned/

This link should illustrate the quality they put out. Here is a quote from the devs, 9heads also uses free programming libraries and engine such as Ogre3D and Bullet Physics proving that you can achieve very nice results with exceptional free/open-source stuff out there.""

reviewText:
Absolutely a fun game with friends-- especially if they have microphones. Three types of monsters, each with their own playstyle that the survivors will have to adapt to in order to survive.

But surviving is not enough, as the longer you take, the less sane you become. You not only imagine sounds that others cannot hear, but you see the faces of the dead, your flashlight flickers without cause, your hearing becomes impaired, and worse.

Your ultimate objective is to find a key to unlock another door that hopefully has the one key you need to unlock your only escape. Be sure to check each drawer, stove, counter top, table, and bucket, because the keys-- and batteries for your flashlight-- could be anywhere, just like the monster.

Did you see Mary when you turned that corner? Hopefully not, because that means she saw you. Did that clock make a loud noise as you passed it? Hope you are just going crazy, because that means the Lurker found you. Did that strange apparition spook you as you turned the corner? Hope not, because any noise you make as a result brings it right to you.

While the game itself is extremely fun with friends who have microphones and with a monster who would rather toy with you than kill you right away, there is a noticeable lack of optimization. I used to be able to run this game well enough 45+ FPS normally on my mid-end system, but it suddenly dropped to 15 and less. Many solutions did not work, but one did; uninstall, reboot, reinstall.

reviewText:
The game is quite fun. However, just as other players have suggested, some of the monsters need to be better balanced. Some monsters are way too OP (Phantom and Lurker especially) while the others (May and Fallen) are very hard to play with. I like the idea behind Fallen especially, but only having 7 seconds to attack a running player at walking speed after spending 5+ minutes trying to get energy is taxing on the fun.

I am also slightly concerned about the price of the game given the amount of content that it has and also how the product itself appears in its current state. There is much potential to this game as it is very unique in that it gives a personal horror experience that is fun with your friends (which you can have up to five of them playing including yourself). However, in its current state, it is not worth $20. I got the game on sale for around $7 and I don't feel I wasted money, however, if I had paid $20 for it, I may have been slightly disappointed. I think $10 would be a fair price for the game in it's current state.

Some suggestions that I have personally is adding some new monsters, like maybe a clown (an omage to Pennywise from IT), warewolf, alien (like alien vs predator)... the more options the better. That goes for the survivors as well. While there may only be 4 survivors total in a given game, giving more characters too choose from would be awesome. There is only one female to choose from in the list of survivors, while there could be an all male team, or an all female team. Giving more options allows players to connect better through the character they choose.

Another critique is that some of the locations are identical. While there are plenty of locations to choose from, the hotels look very similar to each other, and so do the hospitals. It takes away each location's uniqueness. The forest and the diner and warehouse are good locations. But if there are going to be multiple hotels and multiple hospitals it would be wise to consider making them vastly unique from each other.

Overall the game is great, but I would say that the biggest con is that it is overpriced given the amount of conent that it has. When this game is on sale, I recommend getting it, as it is fun to play with friends.

reviewText:
Probably one of the best 5 player co-op games I've ever played!
Much like Evolve, four survivors try to escape from one player-controlled monster.
Scavenging creepy maps in search for randomly spawned items such as batteries, keys, numerical codes (for opening safes), crowbars/hammers, etc.

As survivors, working together is crucial. Voice chat (default C) allows everyone (even the monster) to hear you so don't give away your position. Text chatting on the other hand is only seen by survivors.
Memorizing the map layouts and how to avoid the certain monsters is very important, music changing is a big key in knowing there's a monster near you.


Items:

-Only pick up batteries when your flashlight is about to die, and don't pick up more than one you can only carry the one in your flashlight so don't waste them.
-The crowbar is used to pry off wooden planks blocking doors from pressing left click on them.
-Numerical codes written on paper open only certain safes.
-Keys also only open certain doors so you'll be running back and forth a lot


Monsters:

Lurker
A demon that has a spirit form where they sprint around the map invisible but unable to see or hear survivors. In this form the monster right clicks glowing objects to activate a trap, when a survivor walks past the trap, the object is set off alerting the monster the presence of a survivor. After 20 seconds of the start of the round you can activate physical form which makes you visible, and able to attack but walk much slower. The humans can out-run you and this form only lasts 40 seconds before going back to ghost form. Depending on how long you stay in the physical form, the longer the cool-down is for you to change back from ghost form to physical, so turn off physical form when not needed.
If you're being chased, turned off your flashlight and sprint away, closing doors on them will block them out since Lurkers can't open doors.

Phantom
The phantom is a ghost that can see you by hearing what you do, so shining your light on it and starring it down doesn't mean it knows where you are. When you do something loud such as sprinting, or anything interactive such as opening doors, turning on/off your flashlight and the phantom is near you, he will see you appear as bright white character (reverse silhouette) that can shine through obstacles and walls on his screen and chase you down. This ghost can go through doors, so don't bother closing doors, leave them open for your convenience! This monster requires more stealth then the others since you need to casual walk and stay still most of the time.

Mary
A ghost girl that is an insanely slow character so if you see her just run away. Hiding from her is possible only if you can hide behind a door since that blocks her from charging her attack. Mary is ABLE open doors only in casual walking mode (as long as the doors are unlocked), so if she shes you in a room make sure to hold left-click and keep the door closed to prevent her from opening it behind you! Mary's main attack is Frenze which gives her 4x speed and attack to kill al survivors in her way! Luckily, she needs to charge it up to use it, mainly by being close to survivors. If a survivor is near, shines their flashlight on her, of if she even walks underneath a light (anything that disturtbs" the witch) she gains energy towards Frenzy mode. Her second ability is teleporting so she can very likely teleport in the room you're in. Her primary ability is a frenzy attack
date: if she stares at a survivor for roughly 10 seconds she can charge (twice as fast as your sprinting) for about 8 seconds and kill everyone in the way. The longer the round
recommended:
the more energy Mary gains meaning that she can use her abilities faster and more often.


I would highly recommend this game for a group of friends looking to co-op on something
hoursPlayed:
or if you're into survival horror games working as a team!
There are still a lot of bugs but it's pretty stable.
Also looking forward to the new monsters and features in the new future!

10/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 59 hours of gameplay, lots of hours of watching videos and reading stuff about the game, I'm ready to write a review.
This is, so far, the best survival/horror game I've played in the past few years.
Even though it's an Early Access Game I can absolutely say it's worth the price. 9heads (developer) keeps looking at the feedbacks in the Steam forums, and updates the game regularly.
Most bugs and glitches can be fixed, and 9heads keeps releasing fixes.

One of the best games to play with your friends. Me and my friends had awesome nights playing this, also made some friends in this game.

A few things need to be balanced, and 9heads is taking feedback on that.

reviewText:
It took me a while to get this game to work since i had the issue where my FPS would not go higher than 15 FPS but after some tweaking and one good reboot later i got it to run smoothly and i enjoyed the game alot.
It is specially fun if you play with your friends and i'd imagine that one can easily spend some time playing this game during weekends for jumpscares and laughs.

This game should not be taken too seriosly since the survivor goals tend to feel a little bit tedious and frustrating at times. Clearly it is much more fun to be the monster than a survivor but if you are playing with friends it really does not matter what happens.

The game itself is buggy and still as it seems a work in progress but if you can make it run good you are about to have some good time.

So i would say 3/5 for the overall experience and 5/5 for the spooky atmosphere and that is where this game is at its strongest. I strongly recommend trying this one out specially if it's on sale,

reviewText:
When I found this game - and noticed it was a 4 vs 1 game I was pretty excited.
Got 5 copies, and got 4 friends interested.

Started up the game, found there was a random button and went at it.

Used the oh so fun door controls and try to hold it shut so the monster can get in and eat my face as the spook tunes make my heart race.

Slowly we die off, my room mate is still alive trying to escape our new hell.

He hides in a corner, face first in the wall wishing for the monster just kill him.

10/10

Will die first again, and again.

reviewText: Cannot recommend this enough for a group of friends if you can buy it for all 4-5 people. Even 3 if you have to. Great time. Maps and graphic optimisation drag the game down a bit, there are a couple that seem identical, if not deserve to just be merged into a bigger one because they look very similar in terms of color, style etc. Graphic optimisation here is tough. Not something you should worry about though because the graphics aren't much even on max, and you aren't here for that anyway. The horror is good enough to give this game about 7/10. Above average and greatly worthy of your money and time if you can round up at least 3 people including yourself. If not, you're not a big loss as you can always find good people to play with and the population of lobbys never seems to have decreased. I do feel however that the monsters you can play as, need very VERY close watching from the developers. There looks like there might start to be this trend of: monsters that are just out to kill, not scare the players. This is why I fear the Lurker more than any other monster in the game, because killing the survivors in this game isn't the prime focus, it's more of a balance between wanting to scare them too.\n\nI want people to note that the game's soundtrack is by far one of the best I've seen in a while. For a small time composer, it definetly in my opinion rivals the soundtracks in bigger ones, because the composer (Matt Collins, whom if you search for the Damned soundtrack on youtube, you can find) has just a vast knowledge of how to orchestrate such dynamic, classic and grand pieces.. pieces I hope to see more of, but I doubt I will. Quality soundtracks are hard to come by, not every game's complete soundtrack is actually worth listening to. That being said, please give this game a try if you can gather 2 friends to play with, I promise you're in for a treat. And please remember to note down and give credit to Matt Collins for the game's score, he's talented and you'll see.
