reviewText:
Damned can be a tough sell, and for good reason. Back when I bought it, sitting in a lobby for over a minute without the host starting the game basically guaranteed hard crashes for all involved. This has been (mostly) fixed, the game will still randomly kick people for no reason, and isn't very well optimized, but if playing with people you know you'll be hard pressed to find a better multiplayer horror experience when everything DOES work.

Gameplay:
The game is multiplayer slender with amnesia click-and-hold door controls and a battery/flashlight system that would make Jim Sterling cry. You find keys (rather than notes) and use them to open doors to find more keys until you escape, all while being hunted by one of the various monsters (played by a real person). Each monster has their own little twist on gameplay, and by far the most tense moments of the game are when you're limited in where you can travel (no keys) and don't know which monster's playstyle to counter.

That's what the gameplay is, but is it fun?:
Yes. Play. Damned. With. Friends. Hop in a VC, que it up, and make the monster mute himself except for the occasional brag directly after scoring a kill. You'll be amazed how quickly you can betray someone, locking them out of a room and leaving them to die in order to ensure you stay alive. You'll feel genuine relief when you cycle keys as a team to finally open that last exit door. Resource management with batteries usually feels like a tacked-on timekill mechanic, but in Damned you have to share those resources amongst 4 people, which adds to the urgency quite effectively.

Playing as the monster is a blast too. Sometimes you'll get a series of bad ports as Mary, or noone will hit your traps on Lurker, but setting up a legit jumpscare makes it all worth it. reviewText:
Damned Pros and cons and overall thoughts
Damned is a fun, multiplayer survival horror game where 4 people (Or less) play as survivors while the 5th player chooses one of 4 monsters and has to try and kill the survivors, each monster being unique in it's own way.
===
Pros

*Cool Music/Sound Effects

*Allows Co-Op which most horror games do not have

*Nice Push/Pull system with doors and drawers. (Like an Amnesia: The Dark Descent)

*Unique Character models and graphics

*Tons of maps

*Unique and easy to pick up mechanics

*Simple hosting/connecting to friends

*Good Sp00ks with insanity effects

*Literally like goosebumps the game. (The goosebumps theme fits so well it's not even funny)

===
Cons

*Some maps and monster combinations make the game extremely difficult or too easy

*Some monsters are more overpowered than others

*Some maps are very hard to find keys on. Ex: Black Lake

*Performance problems on the highest settings (And I have a decent gaming computer)
===
All around very fun and unique game experience.
10/10

Will play again.

reviewText:
Probably one of the best 5 player co-op games I've ever played!
Much like Evolve, four survivors try to escape from one player-controlled monster.
Scavenging creepy maps in search for randomly spawned items such as batteries, keys, numerical codes (for opening safes), crowbars/hammers, etc.

As survivors, working together is crucial. Voice chat (default C) allows everyone (even the monster) to hear you so don't give away your position. Text chatting on the other hand is only seen by survivors.
Memorizing the map layouts and how to avoid the certain monsters is very important, music changing is a big key in knowing there's a monster near you.


Items:

-Only pick up batteries when your flashlight is about to die, and don't pick up more than one you can only carry the one in your flashlight so don't waste them.
-The crowbar is used to pry off wooden planks blocking doors from pressing left click on them.
-Numerical codes written on paper open only certain safes.
-Keys also only open certain doors so you'll be running back and forth a lot


Monsters:

Lurker
A demon that has a spirit form where they sprint around the map invisible but unable to see or hear survivors. In this form the monster right clicks glowing objects to activate a trap, when a survivor walks past the trap, the object is set off alerting the monster the presence of a survivor. After 20 seconds of the start of the round you can activate physical form which makes you visible, and able to attack but walk much slower. The humans can out-run you and this form only lasts 40 seconds before going back to ghost form. Depending on how long you stay in the physical form, the longer the cool-down is for you to change back from ghost form to physical, so turn off physical form when not needed.
If you're being chased, turned off your flashlight and sprint away, closing doors on them will block them out since Lurkers can't open doors.

Phantom
The phantom is a ghost that can see you by hearing what you do, so shining your light on it and starring it down doesn't mean it knows where you are. When you do something loud such as sprinting, or anything interactive such as opening doors, turning on/off your flashlight and the phantom is near you, he will see you appear as bright white character (reverse silhouette) that can shine through obstacles and walls on his screen and chase you down. This ghost can go through doors, so don't bother closing doors, leave them open for your convenience! This monster requires more stealth then the others since you need to casual walk and stay still most of the time.

Mary
A ghost girl that is an insanely slow character so if you see her just run away. Hiding from her is possible only if you can hide behind a door since that blocks her from charging her attack. Mary is ABLE open doors only in casual walking mode (as long as the doors are unlocked), so if she shes you in a room make sure to hold left-click and keep the door closed to prevent her from opening it behind you! Mary's main attack is Frenze which gives her 4x speed and attack to kill al survivors in her way! Luckily, she needs to charge it up to use it, mainly by being close to survivors. If a survivor is near, shines their flashlight on her, of if she even walks underneath a light (anything that disturtbs" the witch) she gains energy towards Frenzy mode. Her second ability is teleporting so she can very likely teleport in the room you're in. Her primary ability is a frenzy attack
date: if she stares at a survivor for roughly 10 seconds she can charge (twice as fast as your sprinting) for about 8 seconds and kill everyone in the way. The longer the round
recommended:
the more energy Mary gains meaning that she can use her abilities faster and more often.


I would highly recommend this game for a group of friends looking to co-op on something
hoursPlayed:
or if you're into survival horror games working as a team!
There are still a lot of bugs but it's pretty stable.
Also looking forward to the new monsters and features in the new future!

10/10"

reviewText:
Damned can be a tough sell, and for good reason. Back when I bought it, sitting in a lobby for over a minute without the host starting the game basically guaranteed hard crashes for all involved. This has been (mostly) fixed, the game will still randomly kick people for no reason, and isn't very well optimized, but if playing with people you know you'll be hard pressed to find a better multiplayer horror experience when everything DOES work.

Gameplay:
The game is multiplayer slender with amnesia click-and-hold door controls and a battery/flashlight system that would make Jim Sterling cry. You find keys (rather than notes) and use them to open doors to find more keys until you escape, all while being hunted by one of the various monsters (played by a real person). Each monster has their own little twist on gameplay, and by far the most tense moments of the game are when you're limited in where you can travel (no keys) and don't know which monster's playstyle to counter.

That's what the gameplay is, but is it fun?:
Yes. Play. Damned. With. Friends. Hop in a VC, que it up, and make the monster mute himself except for the occasional brag directly after scoring a kill. You'll be amazed how quickly you can betray someone, locking them out of a room and leaving them to die in order to ensure you stay alive. You'll feel genuine relief when you cycle keys as a team to finally open that last exit door. Resource management with batteries usually feels like a tacked-on timekill mechanic, but in Damned you have to share those resources amongst 4 people, which adds to the urgency quite effectively.

Playing as the monster is a blast too. Sometimes you'll get a series of bad ports as Mary, or noone will hit your traps on Lurker, but setting up a legit jumpscare makes it all worth it. My friends and I have tons of stories along the lines of remember that time I made [friend] scream like a little ♥♥♥♥♥?" Very few games give you that opportunity.

Graphics:
Meh. Mary and Fallen work well because they are meant to look stiff and plodding
date: but lurker looks like the monster from "Boogeyman
recommended: and only will make you jump if he pops up right on your ♥♥♥ (which he often does). Character models are functional, as are animations. Environments are sufficiantly mood-supporting, but a LOT of the levels are re-arranged assets from our asylum level." The most important thing is that the graphics rarely detract from the horror experience.\n\nAudio: Absolutely essential to have a good headset in order to get the full experience with this game. Most monsters set "traps" by interacting with objects in the environment that give off a sound que when the players pass by them. There is no worse feeling than stumbling through a hallway and triggering 3 or 4 traps in close succession
hoursPlayed: basically ensuring the monster knows exactly where you are. Ambient sound when the monster is close or is attacking further crank up the intensity
voteText: and the plinking minimalism of the rest of the audio just accents these bombastic moments even further.\n\nOverall: 6/10
helpfulPercent: 8/10 with lobby of friends. If you can
votesHelpful: buy it on sale or in a 4-pack with friends pitching in
votesTotal: but $20 is a relatively fair price on its own."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Am I seriously missing something here?

I'm not having a whole ton of fun with game. Tons of bugs and glitches everywhere, really bad performance issues. There is no tutorial or anything to help you, well you wont really need any help because all your gonna be doing through the whole game is PICKING UP KEYS AND UNLOCKING DOORS!!!!! Where is the variety guys? C'mon....
The maps are decent but not too special, and how come being a monster just really sucks!?! You would think that you would feel pretty cool being a monster but in this GAME you feel so cheap and pathetic. I was hoping you could do many cool things as a monster like trigger things, make people hallucinate and like fly around and drop in right behind a dude and scare the living daylights out of him. BUT NO! You can't do that, well atleast from my playthroughs I couldn't. As a monster in this game, you run around the area searching for people for hours and hours and hitting them then in one hit, they're dead. Very misleading... I wasn't frightened one bit in this game, the only thing I could say that scared me much was the freaking music that plays when a person is running away from you while your the monster, it just suddenly pops in, scaring the bajeezus outta you. But one poor decision that I hate in this game is that when your the lurker, you can't see anybody until you manifest. I find it very stupid but some people might disagree with me. Only my opinion

All I can say left about this game is that the premise of it sounds incredible but the dev's executed it poorly. I know it's in a earlier stage of development but still feels like a very VERY earlier version of the game that the dev's should only have. PLEASE DEVELOPERS LISTEN OUT!!! Sorry for being harsh but please change some of these decisions that you've made, it would definitely change my thoughts about this a lot. Wait people, till these get fixed, I just can't recommend just yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unplayable.

The potential is there- when and if you can connect to a game. However, this is seemingly impossible. There are maybe 3 hosted games at most at any given time- and there's a good chance only one of them is public (the full one.) Hosting a game is a futile gesture because no one is playing, no one is joining, and you can't play a game alone.

I tried, and I ran around as a ghost with no one to scare or kill for 10 minutes. After I exited the game, Damned didn't understand that I couldn't die (as the ghost,) and therefore couldn't disconnect from the server... ever. It took me 45 minutes to get back to the lobby and then only after restarting my computer, which isn't really a viable option to use in order to shut down/restart the game. Especially a game which requires so much restarting to begin with.

This isn't a beta, it's complete undeveloped and broken. The concept gets a gold star, though.

reviewText: This might very well be the very worst Steam game I have ever played. One hour tops is all it takes to see every single detail this game has to offer. Nothing can compare to the disappointment of the moment of finally getting far enough to get the hammer or crowbar (did I mention this game is nearly impossible for the survivors to win?) only to find out that they aren't weapons, they're just glorified keys, used only for opening doors. This game has no spark of creativity, and no loving touch at all, it's just half ♥♥♥♥♥ garbage with as little actual content as physically possible, in the form of a barely playable game. Even managing that, the game still is riddled with bugs. The fact that this game is being sold for 20 dollars on Steam is an insult to cheaper games that vastly outshine it, and an insult to the customer, who won't get more than an afternoon out of it. I didn't even buy this game, I got it as a gift from a friend, and even I'm insulted.

reviewText: I never thought I would enjoy a game that treads to close to the note collector genre" so heavily
date: but here I am. Damned is  an asymmetric 5-player multiplayer game where one player controls one of three different monsters
recommended: each with different abilities and methods of detecting the humans
hoursPlayed: and the other players play as humans trying to escape by finding keys and tools in the environment to make it through to the exit. The game has 12 maps
voteText: giving it a good amount of replayability. The voice chat system was one of my favorite parts of the game
helpfulPercent: featuring a 3D audio option that makes each player's voice come through their character's position instead of being global
votesHelpful: encouraging them to stick together in standard horror movie fashion while also allowing the monster to taunt them.\n\nThe thing that I like about this game is that unlike other asymmetrical games like Evolve
votesTotal: Damned isn't afraid to kill off players. It treats the humans the same way that any horror movie would
votesFunny: and if they don't stick together and find a way out quickly they aren't going to survive. The keys can be pretty well-hidden
commentsCount: and Damned is the only game where I've ever seen a group of players slowly succumb one by one to the realization that they might not ever find the key they missed somewhere
column16: if the key even existed at all. The tension of new players figuring out what to do and what not to do to avoid alerting the monster while finding their way out is a lot of fun
column17: and while I haven't played past that point to know what it'll be like once I know all the tricks
column18: I think there's enough content to it that I would still enjoy it.\n\nThe big problem with the game is that it's pretty buggy in its current state
column19: despite no longer being in early access. When I first started playing the game it had capped itself to 15 FPS
column20: and the only way to fix it was to restart my computer. Even after that
column21: the game is generally poorly optimized from what I've seen from other players (I was able to run it at a pretty consistent 80-90 FPS
column22: which isn't really ideal since I have a 144 hz monitor and a computer that should be running it at far past that framerate
column23: but oh well). The other issue is that the game isn't exactly populated. A quick look at the server list showed 7 lobbies
column25: and 1 of those had a ping of over 1000. This is the sort of game where you should buy a bundle and play with a group of friends instead of relying on random players
column26: but it's more fun with friends anyways so I didn't mind.\n\nIn its current state I wouldn't recommend this game at all for $20
column27: but it seems to go on sale in various indie bundles fairly often (I bought a four-pack of the game for like $1 or so at some point or another)

reviewText:
You've gotta ask yourselves who is f*cking who for RockPaperShotgun/Kotaku and Eurogamer to recommend this piece of sh*t game.  Gamergate,yo!

******DONT BUY THIS GAME.****  Maybe at a sale where's its like 1 euro.. maybe.

I bought the pack and for 5 a piece.. Yea haha not worth it.

The gamer experience, you may encounter when playing this game.

Start up game, have a tiny window. Go to settings, selecting 1920x1080 does not mean fullscreen apparantly. Drag window after you manage to unstick your mouse. Select 'Full screen' aaand- CRASH.  Looking promising already. When killing the program dont kill the 'Game' kill the other 'Game' in your programs, killing the first one doesnt solve jack sh*t.

Restart the game, oh! Full screen! .. But why is the image so small? Check Gamma settings, drag it ALL the way up to high in order to see all the individual slabs of gray, go back to the home screen and .. Woa, there was another image here? No, nope, its one image, just dark as f*ck which made you think 3/4 of your screen is just black by default.

Alright! Initial grievances are forgiven and forgotten, lets do this sh*t! Start a game, looking for the lobby created by a friend. Er... its here... SOMEWHERE... FOUND IT! Locked the lobby with a password so we can be noobs amongst friends. Fill in password... Nothing happens.. Did I misspell it? I guess I did, lets try again.. Nope.. I spelled it right but it wont let me in. Its not even giving me a 'this aint the password, you fool', the password screen just poofs .. Did I crash again? Oh, nope, and you can start your search for that one specific lobby all over again.

Restart the game.

Alright, all in Lobby, lets do this. First impressions of the ingame enviroment. This is dark as f*ck! Where's my flashlight? Its not F, not E... Where dafuq is it? Right click?! What? .. Oh okay then. Picking up items, E? Nope. Left click. Opening doors, E? ... No.. more clicking. Well, not so much clicking as dragging apparantly. Okay I got keys, I got batteries, dont know what the hell is going on but lets do this. How do I acces my inventory? Can I acces my inventory? I cannot acces my inventory, but then how will I know what i've picked up? Dont question this sh*t, just roll with it this game will not explain sh*t to you. Mash your face against all the doors because its a hassle to try and open them and to figure out if you have the right key for this door or not.  I have 3 keys, can I toggle between them? No? So, should I assume that I use all the keys that I have on this one door that I'm currently humping?

The door may be partially open, you may smash your weight in full against the door. That thing aint opening till you click and drag its ♥♥♥ open.

HOLY SH*T WHAT WAS THAT. I am legit scared.. Why are there hands coming out of the floor?!

Mini heart attack because my friend killed us all. Start a new lobby, now filled with extra randomers, it's all good. Start game, repeat. Running around the game for a full 20 minutes only to realise that our monster left, or disconnected or maybe more likely, crashed. Find out that you could open cabininets 'n shizzle, did I mention this game doesnt tell you sh*t?

Start a new game, choose to be a monster this time. Got to be a Monster for a whole 5 seconds before CRASHHH.

Not even 1 hour of play time, 3 crashes...  I'd grade this game a 2/10 would crash again.

reviewText:
Quick Review

Damned provides a unique spin on the Slenderman game genre of picking up keys and other objectives in order to complete a level while an evil entity chases you. Not only does it add co-op, but it adds an asymetric mechanic where the human players can work together to find the objects in order to escape the 1 player who plays as a monster, seeking to kill all the humans (can anyone say Evolve?).

The horror of Damned doesn't last very long. For the first few hours of your playtime with this game, it will be very terrifying, being stalked by one of three monsters available to the player. Moving through one of the several dark environments the game bestows upon you is unsettling and nerve wrackcing. However, the scares begin to calm down and the game loses it's horror element.

That doesn't mean the game is ruined though, as it still is a fun game of cat and mouse. The mice (humans) running around and madly collecting keys to open up more doors to find more keys is still a fun game as you try to stay alive. Unfortunately, the game is quite boring with 2 players and sometimes even 3 won't do the job. In order to experience the game truly is to have at least 4 or 5 players to play with (at least 3 humans and 1 player monster).

I'd wait till this game goes on a good sale and pick up a 4-pack to play with friends.

7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game has a good concept, but the monster is overpowered. It's extremely easy for the monster to just sit and wait on the survivors to come and then it's a quick kill. The items you have to hunt are too ambiguious and you spend the majority of the time running from room to room looking for a very small item that is easily missed then running back to EVERY door and safe you have come across to see if it opens the said door. If it does, there's a 75% chance that the door you just opened has nothing of value.

Great concept, but the items you have to find need to be made simpler because right now it just goes on forever looking for items and it's way too easy for the monster to find and kill the survivors.

reviewText:
Damned is a 3D horror co-op multiplayer game.

After many normal horror games I have encountered a multiplayer version !!
To begin with, you do need a separate account in order to play online. (I hate that)
Personally, I would only want to play this game with friends.
Playing with unknown people sometimes ruins the horror experience.

It is a game where a few sessions are fun.
Unfortunately, you run into problems quickly.

Game looks pretty good.
Control are fine and you get used to it after a short time.
Unfortunately, the game has many errors / bugs.
And it sometimes ruins the game a little bit.
AI does not function properly and that is a shame.

Game is already very extensive.
Various monsters and some maps, but.... I want more !!!
Unfortunately I don't think there is enough considering the normal price.

This is not an FPS so no weapons and only a flashlight.
Understand also that horror game as it should be and therefore this is not a game for me.

The price is very high for this game and I'll hope it will drop in price or get frequent sales.
And especially for a 4 pack would be important since this is a multiplayer game so that you immediately can play with your friends.

Hope that the makers fix all bugs so the game is a fun experience for everyone.

I give it a 7/10 and fairly high because it is quite original concepts is that you do not see much.
I think this game can be very good.

But I stopped playing after a few hours.
I wanted to to shoot some freaking zombies / monsters..... !!

Let me at least kick someone their ♥♥♥??? with a flashlight !!!

reviewText:
I wrote a full review that you can read here: http://rgz.ca/gaming/damned-review-stereotypical-horror/

tl;dr:

I won’t deny that the game had potential. The fact that it is doing something similar to Evolve, one of this year’s major titles, but in more of a survival horror setting and less of an eSports setting shows that. The fact of the matter is that it is poorly designed, slow, isn’t scary, rehashes survival horror concepts that are both lamented and don’t make a lot of sense to begin with, and is unpolished on top of that. It is unpolished to the point that you may be completely unable to play the game for hours on end or give up on trying before you even get to play it at all. I had a hard time getting the other members of the team I played with to stick with it for this review. That should say something about it there. It had potential but it missed its mark by a long shot.

The game itself is mediocre at best, but that's not why I don't recommend this game. The customer service is simply dreadful. I've now sent 4 emails to the devs, all of which have been completely ignored. I also actually spoke to one of the devs on the community page, who promptly stopped responding when I raised an actual point.

Sure, you might have an hour or two of fun with your friends, but if the slightest thing goes wrong with your game, good luck getting it fixed.

Seriously, until they actually get their ♥♥♥♥ together and start supporting the customers, this game is not even worth glancing at.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Damned is a really fun Survival Horror game where both the survivors and the monster are players. The (maximum of 4) Survivors run around the map rushing to find the different keys/codes to open doors/safes whilst trying to avoid the Monster, who is trying to kill them (there are only 2 types of monster at the time of this review). This can lead to some pretty tense moments of blubbering in a corner whilst the monster metaphorically sniffs around trying to find you. The surprising thing about Damned is that even though it's in alpha, it's still a really good game! Yes, they have bugs to fix, but lately they have really gotten around to fixing a good majority of them.

At the time of this review"
date: the game has a relatively small playerbase outside of the swarm of players every major update. If you're going to buy this game
recommended: the best way to do enjoy it would be to buy it alongside your friends
hoursPlayed: or to get the multi-copy pack so nobody gets left out."
